pulmonary artery.cleaned_definition: Originating from the right ventricle of the heart, this vital organ carries deoxygenated blood towards the lungs, where it undergoes oxygenation and gas exchange. It occupies the middle mediastinum area, branching off into two major tubes that head towards the right and left lungs, respectively. The branch directed at the right lung is positioned in front of the right mainstem bronchus, whereas the branch going towards the left lung is situated above the left mainstem bronchus. This structure is relatively short and wide, with the main section measuring approximately 5 cm in length and 3 cm in diameter. Its two branches have an average diameter of about 2.7-2.9 cm. Composed of three layers, similar to other arteries of significant size, its structure is complex, encompassing an arterial tree, an extensive capillary bed, and a venular tree, altogether playing a crucial role in the body's circulatory system by ensuring the transfer of blood to the lungs for gas exchange. There are variations in the size and diameter of its branches, particularly influenced by biological sex at birth.
relations: the right ventricle of the heart

pulmonary embolism.cleaned_definition:
This condition occurs when substances that have migrated from other parts of the body through the bloodstream block an artery in the lungs. This typically happens when thrombi from deep veins break free and travel to the pulmonary circulation, leading to the obstruction of pulmonary vessels which in turn, hampers gas exchange and circulation. The lower lobes are more commonly affected than the upper ones, and it's usual for both lungs to be involved. Depending on their size, these obstructions can lodge in the main pulmonary artery for larger instances, or block peripheral arteries when smaller.

The bronchovascular configuration plays a pivotal role in interpreting CT scans aimed at evaluating this condition. Segmental arteries, which align closely with the bronchial tree branches, are located medially in the upper lobes and laterally in the lower lobes, lingula, and right middle lobe. 

Conclusion: This vascular obstruction in the lungs is a severe health issue that significantly affects the bronchovascular structure and the lungs' function overall. Recognizing how this condition is spatially related to other anatomical structures aids in precise diagnosis and treatment. Immediate medical intervention is crucial upon experiencing symptoms indicative of this condition.
relations: segmental arteries (in the lower lobes, lingula, and right middle lobe)

rectum.cleaned_definition: This structure serves as the final straight segment of the large intestine in humans and other species, being about 12 centimeters in length and located at the end of the gastrointestinal tract before it transitions into the anal canal, which measures around 4 centimeters in length. Originating at the rectosigmoid junction near the third sacral vertebra or sacral promontory, this organ initially matches the diameter of the sigmoid colon but expands to form the rectal ampulla towards its end, which concludes at the anorectal ring or the dentate line. Lacking the typical features of the rest of the colon such as taenia coli, haustra, and omental appendices, this muscular tube is distinct in appearance and structure. It runs along the anterior surface of the sacrum and coccyx within the posterior pelvic cavity, showing significant flexures along its course, including the sacral and the anorectal flexures, and is supported by three lateral bends. Venous drainage involves the superior, middle, and inferior rectal veins, with the upper portion draining into the portal system and the lower portion into the internal iliac vein. Internally, it is divided into several chambers, each partly segmented from the others by transverse folds, with its mucosa consisting of epithelial tissue and goblet cells for mucus secretion. Ultimately, it acts as the final reservoir for feces before elimination, playing a critical role in the waste disposal process of the body.
relations: located along the anterior surface of
portal venous system (via superior rectal veins)

renal artery.cleaned_definition: This vital structure in human anatomy emerges from the lateral aspect of the abdominal aorta, specifically around the L1/L2 intervertebral disk, just below the superior mesenteric artery's origin. Each is approximately 1 to 2 inches (4 to 6 centimeters) long and 5 mm to 6 mm in diameter. They make their way into the kidneys at the renal hilum, serving as the gateway for vessels and nerves. Moving laterally towards the kidney's hilum, they are positioned posterior to the renal veins, nerves, and the pancreas. At the hilum, this structure bifurcates into anterior and posterior segments, supplying 75% and 25% of the blood flow, respectively, and gives rise to five segmental arteries. The right one is anterior to the inferior vena cava at the beginning, moving closer to the shorter right renal vein as it proceeds. Meanwhile, the left one runs more horizontally, found just behind the left renal vein before reaching the kidney's hilum. At this junction, they divide further to nourish the nephrons. Along the kidney's lateral and slightly posterior border runs an imaginary line, the line of Brodel, indicating the territory supplied by the anterior and posterior divisions of this structure. Essentially, this structure is a short paired entity, branching into smaller arteries that facilitate blood flow to the nephrons.
relations: the lateral aspect of the abdominal aorta
the kidney at the renal hilum
the renal veins, nerves, and the pancreas
the shorter right renal vein (right side)

renal vein.cleaned_definition: These structures are vital components of the human anatomy, tasked with the function of moving deoxygenated blood away from the kidneys. Each kidney is serviced by one of these vessels, which navigate the abdominal cavity medially to join the inferior vena cava, mirroring the path of the renal arteries. The vessel on the left is notably longer. They are characterized as asymmetrically paired vessels that ferry blood lacking oxygen to the heart via the inferior vena cava. While traversing anterior to the renal arteries, the one on the right side gathers blood solely from the kidney. In contrast, its counterpart on the left side also collects from other organs, including the left gonadal vein, left inferior phrenic vein, and left adrenal veins. Each splits into two segments upon entering the kidneys to efficiently facilitate the drainage of both front and back sections, also aiding in the removal of blood from the ureter. This crucial function underscores their role in the circulatory system, aiding in blood circulation maintenance.
relations: left gonadal (ovarian/testicular) vein, left inferior phrenic vein, and left adrenal veins (left side)

rib.cleaned_definition:
In human anatomy, this structure is a long, curved bone part of the protective structure for the thorax. It is flat, narrow, and presents a curved body or shaft that is concave on the internal surface, enclosing a costal groove for neurovascular bundle protection and pathway. Each end connects with costal cartilage, enabling articulation with the sternum. These bones are thin, with a significant curve at the costal angle, indicating a turn anterolaterally. The head is wedge-shaped, featuring two articular facets divided by a crest. The larger facet articulates with the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body, and the smaller facet with the inferior costal facet of the vertebra above.

It articulates posteriorly with the vertebral column and terminates anteriorly as cartilage, forming the protective cage. They assist in ventilation by moving during chest expansion, facilitating lung inflation. Variations exist in structure, notably in the first, second, and tenth to twelfth pairs, presenting distinctions such as the first having two articular facets and the latter not attaching directly to the sternum. Abnormalities like dislocation, costochondritis, osteoporosis, and tumors may occur. Typically, humans possess 24 of these structures in 12 pairs, with an occasional congenital overdevelopment leading to an extra one on top of the first.

rib 1.cleaned_definition: This structure sits at the very top of the cage that shields the thorax, serving as a crucial anatomical marker. Its unique shape is distinguished by a wedge-shaped head with two joining surfaces, divided by a crest, allowing for articulation with adjacent vertebrae. The shaft is notably thin, flat, and curved, featuring a costal groove along its inner surface to safeguard and guide the neurovascular bundle. This part concludes with a connection point for cartilage, promoting its junction with the sternum. Composed of a head, neck, and body, this organ not only articulates with the respective vertebral body and the vertebra above but also independently connects with the sternum. As a border of the superior thoracic aperture, it plays a vital role in forming the thoracic protection structure, offering coverage for thoracic organs with its highly vascular and trabecular nature, surrounded by a compact bone layer.
relations: superior costal facet of its corresponding vertebral body

rib 10.cleaned_definition: Located in the thoracic region, this structure is a flat and curved bone, with its curvature most pronounced at the costal angle. The body of this structure is slender, featuring a concave internal surface and ending with a cup for the costal cartilage, which allows for articulation with the sternum. It is characterized by a costal groove on its surface, providing a path for the neurovascular bundle. The head of this bone is wedge-shaped, featuring two articular facets, one for articulation with the corresponding vertebra and the other with the vertebra above. As part of the rib cage, this organ plays a vital role in protecting the thoracic cavity's vital organs and aiding in lung inflation during breathing.

rib 2.cleaned_definition:
This structure is a component of the thoracic cage, effectively safeguarding the chest area. It nestles snugly between its neighboring ribs, securing itself to both the thoracic vertebrae at the back and the sternum at the front. Its body is characterized by a slender, flat, and arched form, most noticeable at the costal angle where the structure shifts anterolaterally. The underside is hollowed out to form a costal groove, safeguarding and guiding the accompanying neurovascular bundle. The extremity of the body is fashioned into a receptacle for the costal cartilage, ensuring a joint with the sternum. The proximal end is distinguished by a wedge-shaped head with dual articulating facets, bordered by a segment of bone. The superior facet integrates with the corresponding vertebral body’s superior costal facet, whereas the inferior one joins with the vertebra above's inferior costal facet. Beyond its head, the structure extends into a neck and then into its slender, arched body. Besides its attachments to the thoracic vertebrae and the sternum, it serves as an anchor for certain deep back muscles at the costal angle, while the costal groove plays a key role in protecting and channeling the neurovascular bundle.

Relation: attached to (posteriorly), Anatomical structure: thoracic vertebrae
Relation: attached to (anteriorly), Anatomical structure: sternum
Relation: serves as an anchor for, Anatomical structure: deep back muscles
Relation: provides a path for (via costal groove), Anatomical structure: neurovascular bundle

rib 3.cleaned_definition: Located within the thoracic cage, this structure serves as a key component in forming the protective enclosure for the chest. Its body, or shaft, is characterized by a slender, flattened shape that curves most prominently at the costal angle where it turns anterolaterally. The internal side features a concavity and houses the costal groove, safeguarding and directing the neurovascular bundle. The body culminates in a receptacle for the costal cartilage, facilitating articulation with the sternum. Comprising a head, neck, and body, the head presents itself with a wedge shape, outfitted with two articular facets divided by a bony wedge, facilitating articulation with the spine. This part plays a crucial role in the rib cage, aiding in the protection of thoracic organs and assisting in the respiratory process through its movement that allows lung expansion.

rib 4.cleaned_definition: Situated in the thoracic region as part of the rib cage, this structure is a flat, curved bone recognized by its thin and flat body. It becomes most noticeable at the costal angle, where it turns anterolaterally. The inside surface is concave, featuring a costal groove that not only protects but also guides the neurovascular bundle. This bone concludes with a terminal cup for costal cartilage, ensuring articulation with the sternum. Its head, wedge-shaped, presents two articular facets divided by a ridge of bone. The larger facet joins with the superior costal facet of the matching vertebral body, whereas the smaller facet connects with the adjacent vertebra above. Moreover, the costal angle signifies where certain deep back muscles attach.

rib 6.cleaned_definition: Located within the thoracic cage, this structure is essential in forming the protective barrier for the thorax. It showcases a distinct curve at its costal angle, turning anterolaterally, with its internal surface being concave and featuring a costal groove for the neurovascular bundle. The shaft is characterized by its slender, flat, and curved nature, ending in a cup for the costal cartilage, which facilitates articulation with the sternum. The head presents a wedge shape with two articular facets divided by a crest, where the larger facet interacts with the corresponding vertebral body's superior costal facet, and the smaller one with the vertebra above. This bone articulates posteriorly with the vertebral column and extends anteriorly as cartilage, which connects to the sternum, thus encapsulating the heart and lungs within a bony encasement.

rib 8.cleaned_definition: Situated in the thoracic region, this structure is part of the protective cage surrounding the thoracic organs. Its appearance is characterized by a narrow, flat, and curved form. The internal surface is notably concave, featuring a costal groove that safeguards and guides the neurovascular bundle. The body terminates in a cup designed for the costal cartilage, facilitating an articulation with the sternum indirectly. Comprising a head, neck, and body, the head presents a wedge-shape with two articular facets, divided by a crest of bone, designed for articulation with the corresponding and the vertebra above it. The presence of a costal groove along its internal surface ensures protection and a pathway for the neurovascular bundle, with the body concluding in a cup for the costal cartilage, which connects to the sternum indirectly. This organ is recognized as a false rib due to its lack of direct sternum attachment, instead connecting indirectly through the cartilage of the rib above.

rib cartilage.cleaned_definition:
This structure is vital in offering both structural support and flexibility to the thoracic cage, being essentially crafted from hyaline cartilage which facilitates the rib's connection with the sternum. Located at the rib cage's front, it binds the ribs to the sternum, ensuring a durable yet pliable linkage. Its appearance is marked by a pale blue-white hue, characteristic of the hyaline make-up, ensuring a smooth, resilient surface that reduces friction. Shaped thinly, flat, and curved, its most noted curvature is at the costal angle, highlighting a concave internal space for the protective routing of the neurovascular bundle. They enable the ribs' movement with the sternum, connecting directly or indirectly, with their lateral ends merging seamlessly into the rib's bony part, highlighting a cardinal link that ensures the thoracic organs' protection and aids in ventilation.

Relation: provides direct or indirect attachment, Anatomical structure: sternum
Relation: continuous with, Anatomical structure: osseous tissue of the rib
Relation: contains, Anatomical structure: costal groove
Relation: offers protection and a path for, Anatomical structure: neurovascular bundle
relations: offers protection and a path for

right adrenal gland.cleaned_definition: This triangular-shaped organ is a crucial component of the endocrine system, positioned atop the right kidney and in immediate vicinity to the inferior vena cava (IVC) and the liver. It possesses dimensions of roughly 50 mm in height, 30 mm in width, and 10 mm in thickness, with an approximate weight of 5 grams. This structure receives its blood supply from three sources: the superior arteries stemming from the inferior phrenic arteries, the middle artery from the aorta, and the inferior artery from the renal arteries. Typically, a single central vein drains this organ, directing blood into the IVC on its side and into the renal vein on the opposing side. It is surrounded by the renal fascia of Gerota, kept apart from the kidney by a layer of fascia. Being retroperitoneal, it is covered anteriorly by parietal peritoneum only. Its proximity to the liver, IVC, and diaphragm underscores the importance for surgeons specializing in this area to have a comprehensive understanding due to its closeness to these critical structures.

right anterior eyeball.cleaned_definition: This structure, positioned at the forefront of the right eye, serves as a crucial sensorial unit for catching and transmitting visual signals to the brain. Constituted by three primary layers - fibrous, vascular, and the retina - it resides within the orbit, safeguarded by fatty cushions. Its globe-like shape, accentuated by a frontal protrusion, encloses the anterior chamber, a section filled with liquid situated right behind the cornea and before the iris. Key components include the cornea, iris, lens, and aqueous humor, indispensable for both seeing and the eye's motility. This organ's connection to the optic nerve ensures the relay of visual data to the brain, encased by the fibrous tunic that combines the cornea at the front and the sclera at the back, with the aqueous humor-filled anterior chamber nestled between the cornea and iris. These elements collectively facilitate the perception and interpretation of visual surroundings.
relations: orbit (bony eye socket of the skull)
fibrous tunic (anterior cornea and posterior sclera)

right anterior inferior segment of liver.cleaned_definition: Located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, this structure is positioned beneath the diaphragm and above the stomach, right kidney, and intestines, extending from the fifth intercostal space in the midclavicular line to the right costal margin. The liver, displaying a prism or wedge shape, is of a pinkish brown hue, with a soft, highly vascular, and friable texture. Comprising two main lobes, the liver is further divided into eight segments, which include thousands of lobules. These lobules are interconnected through small ducts that lead into larger ones, culminating in the common hepatic duct. This segment is vital for the precise localization of hepatic lesions before surgery. It is intricately associated with the gallbladder and right kidney, bordered by the falciform ligament, which divides the liver into left and right halves. The round ligament of the liver, a remnant of the umbilical vein, is located along the falciform ligament's free edge. The duodenum and various portal structures also maintain a direct connection through the hepatoduodenal ligament.
relations: right upper quadrant of the abdomen
round ligament of the liver (via free-edge of falciform ligament)

right anterior superior segment of liver.cleaned_definition:
This structure is a specific area within the hepatic tissue. It is positioned in the upper right section of the abdominal space, directly underneath the diaphragm and above the stomach, right kidney, and intestines. This portion of the liver, forming part of its larger right lobe located in the right upper quadrant, assumes a prism or wedge shape. It's characterized by a pinkish-brown hue, a soft texture, exhibits high vascularity, and is prone to damage. Being a segment of the larger right lobe, it plays a crucial role both in nutrient metabolism and in the detoxification process. The liver is divided into two primary lobes, with this segment being a constituent of the right lobe. It forms when the right hepatic duct merges with anterior and posterior sectoral ducts from specific hepatic segments. When viewed via contrast-enhanced CT, it is delineated by the right hepatic vein on one side and the middle hepatic vein on the other, highlighting its proximity to significant vascular structures.

Relation: located within, Anatomical structure: liver
Relation: situated above, Anatomical structure: stomach, right kidney, intestines
Relation: underneath, Anatomical structure: diaphragm
Relation: lies between, Anatomical structure: right hepatic vein (right posterior sector and right anterior sector), middle hepatic vein (right anterior sector and segment IV)

right breast.cleaned_definition: This organ is situated on the anterior segment of the thoracic wall, in the pectoral area, reaching from the lateral edge of the sternum to the mid-axillary line and vertically from the 2nd to the 6th costal cartilages. It is positioned over the pectoralis major and serratus anterior muscles. Its shape generally resembles a tear and encapsulates lobules and ducts akin to bunches of grapes, with its size and contour largely defined by subcutaneous adipose tissue. This structure is equipped for milk production during lactation, comprising 15 to 20 lobes that are circularly arranged. Each lobe houses numerous lobules, ending in bulbs capable of milk production, all connected through a network of ducts leading to the nipple, surrounded by the areola. It is comprised of glandular, fibrous, and fatty tissues, where the glandular component includes the lobes and ducts. It is anchored to the chest wall by ligaments, lying atop the pectoralis major muscle and is vascularized by a network that includes the internal mammary perforators and the thoracoacromial artery.

right cheek.cleaned_definition:
This structure refers to the facial area on the right side, nestled between the eye and jawline, forming part of the facial contour involved in the digestive process, speech, and emotional display. Complex in nature, it comprises muscular fibers, vasculature, adipose tissue, minor salivary glands, and various other components. The outermost layer is the epidermis, home to hair follicles and glands that offer protection against microbes. Positioned beneath the eye and to the side of the nasal structure, it features fat deposits covered by the epidermis. Integral muscles such as the levator labii superioris alaeque nasii play a role in nostril and upper lip movement.

The form of the face, including this area, owes to the underlying skeletal framework, muscular layers, and subcutaneous fat presence. Extending from the nasal to the aural areas, it sits anteriorly on the head, beneath the ocular area but atop the mandibular line, belonging to the buccal region noted for its role in mastication, verbal communication, and various facial expressions. Innervation is primarily through the infraorbital and zygomaticofacial nerves. Anatomically, it finds itself anteriorly between the eye and jaw, superior to the mouth region but below the eye and temporal areas, and flanked medially by the nasal region and laterally by the ear area. Composed of multiple muscle groups, adipose tissue, and glandular elements, its epidermal covering acts as a barrier against external elements.

right eustachian tube bone.cleaned_definition: This structure is essential for connecting the middle ear to the nasopharynx, crucial in maintaining pressure equilibrium within the middle ear relative to the external atmosphere. It is composed of two main parts: a bony section and a fibrocartilaginous section. The former, making up one-third of its total length, is embedded within the petrous part of the temporal bone, extending about 12 millimeters. It starts at an opening on the anterior wall of the middle ear, where the petrous and squamous parts of the temporal bone meet, coursing into the tympanic cavity whose walls are congruent with those of the middle ear. This structure, in its entirety, spans roughly 36 mm in adults, descending, advancing, and medially directing from the middle ear. Its lateral third, a 12 mm bony segment, originates from the anterior wall of the tympanic cavity, while the medial two-thirds, a 24 mm fibrocartilaginous segment, extends into the nasopharynx, opening around 1.25 cm behind the inferior turbinate's posterior end. Located within the parapharyngeal space, it traverses from the middle ear's front wall to the nasopharynx's sidewall. The bony segment forms an irregular sac-like structure rather than a tubular one, acting as an anterior extension of the middle ear cavity or "Protympanum". The ear side, or isthmus, of this structure is its narrowest point and is often the site for potential obstructive pathology leading to chronic ear conditions.
relations: petrous part of the temporal bone
anterior wall of the tympanic cavity

right eyeball.cleaned_definition:
This spheroidal sensory organ serves the crucial function of receiving and transmitting visual information to the brain. It is encased in a protective bony cavity known as the orbit. This structure is akin to a simple camera, comprising a retina that is a densely metabolic nerve tissue layer filled with millions of light receptors (photoreceptors). Inside, the organ is supported by a transparent gel-like substance, the vitreous humor, maintaining its shape. The external shell is made of a dense fibrous tissue, the sclera, which encases most of the organ and offers attachment points for movement-controlling muscles. The clear, dome-shaped cornea covers the front, while the iris, the eye's colored segment, aids in light regulation. Additionally, the lens, situated inside, concentrates light rays onto the retina. The ciliary body, responsible for aqueous humor production, and the choroid, a vascular membrane behind the retina, are vital components.

Relations:
1. Relation: housed within, Anatomical structure: orbit
2. Relation: connected to, Anatomical structure: optic nerve (CN II)
3. Relation: provides attachments for, Anatomical structure: extraocular muscles
4. Relation: covers (the front of), Anatomical structure: cornea
5. Relation: facilitates movement of, Anatomical structure: sclera
6. Relation: regulates light entry into, Anatomical structure: iris
7. Relation: focuses light onto, Anatomical structure: retina
8. Relation: produces aqueous humor for, Anatomical structure: ciliary body
9. Relation: situated between (the retina and the sclera), Anatomical structure: choroid
relations: situated between (the retina and the sclera)

right femur.cleaned_definition: This structure is the sole bone in the human thigh, extending from the hip to the knee. It features two rounded ends and a lengthy middle shaft, mirroring the typical depiction of a bone with a cylindrical shaft capped by two bulbous ends. The upper region connects to the hip joint, housing the femoral head, neck, trochanters, intertrochanteric crest, and line. Its shaft is pivotal in supporting the body's weight and shaping the thigh, with a slight inward curve. The lower region is integral to the knee joint's formation, engaging with the tibia and patella through its medial and lateral condyles. Being the longest, heaviest, and strongest bone, it can withstand forces between 1,800 and 2,500 pounds. Its forward convexity and the supporting linea aspera at the back enhance its strength. The shaft expands into a wider base at the lower end, connecting with the knee joint. Moreover, it serves as an attachment point for numerous muscles and ligaments like the gluteus medius and minimus, alongside housing the primary blood supply for the lower extremity through the femoral artery, with supplemental circulation to the femoral head from the foveal artery, and nourishment to its shaft and lower portion via the deep femoral artery's perforating branches. In essence, this bone is central to weight support and mobility in the lower limb, characterized by its distinct shape, and functions intricately linked with surrounding anatomical entities.
relations: site of origin and attachment for

right gluteus maximus.cleaned_definition: Situated in the buttocks, this structure is one of the human body's strongest muscles, attaching to the coccyx and nearby bones. It stands out as the largest and most superficial among the three gluteal muscles, contributing significantly to the hips' shape and appearance. This organ is a broad, thick, quadrilateral mass, foremost in defining the buttocks' contour. Below it, the gluteus medius and, further beneath, the gluteus minimus, exist as integral parts of what are commonly known as the glutes. Fibers from this muscle extend into various body parts, including the femur and the iliotibial tract. It is the outermost layer among the gluteal muscles, enveloped by a thin fascia separating it from the subcutaneous tissue below. The underlying surface of this muscle conceals numerous anatomical entities, such as the gluteus medius muscle, pelvic bones, the origins of the hamstring muscles, and multiple lateral rotators of the hip.
relations: proximal attachments of the hamstring muscles

right gluteus medius.cleaned_definition: Located beneath the gluteus maximus, this muscle emerges from the outer surface of the ilium, stretching downward to anchor on the greater trochanter of the femur. It manifests as a fan-shaped entity, narrowing as it ascends towards the ilium. Structurally, it is a broad, thick formation, lying on the pelvis's outer aspect. Its posterior segment is concealed by the gluteus maximus, and the anterior portion is demarcated by the gluteal aponeurosis. This structure collaborates with the gluteus minimus in supporting the hip area, playing a critical role in stabilizing the lower limb and pelvis for normal walking movements. Its connection points include the ilium and the lateral aspect of the greater trochanter, with a portion overlaid by the gluteus maximus in the lower third, influencing the contour of the buttocks.
relations: partially covered by (on its lower-third part)

right gluteus minimus.cleaned_definition: Positioned deep in the posterior region of the hip, this small, triangular muscle extends from the ilium's gluteal surface to the femur's proximal end, residing just under another muscle responsible for similar functions. It is notably triangular, originating lower on the ilium and attaching itself to the femur. Functioning alongside its neighboring muscle, it aids in thigh abduction, internal rotation, and stabilizing the pelvis. Innervation is provided by the superior gluteal nerve, spanning from L4 to S1, while its blood supply comes from both the superior gluteal artery and trochanteric anastomosis.
relations: anterior aspect of the greater trochanter of the femur

right heart atrium.cleaned_definition: Positioned in the heart's upper right quadrant, this chamber serves as the initial point of entry for deoxygenated blood from the body, lying superior to another chamber tasked with subsequent blood propulsion. As one of the heart's four chambers, this structure distinguishes itself by a notably less muscular wall than its counterparts and possesses an auricle, resembling a floppy dog ear, to expand its volume. Deoxygenated blood from the superior and inferior vena cava flows into this chamber, directed afterward into the lower chamber below it through a one-way valve. Spatially, it lies above the mentioned lower chamber and is delineated by specific thoracic vertebral levels depending on the body's position. Malfunctions in this organ, arising either congenitally or from issues in adjacent muscular or valve structures, can lead to arrhythmias, blood clots, or heart failure, highlighting its importance in the circulatory process.

right heart ventricle.cleaned_definition: Positioned in the heart's lower right area, beneath the right atrium and across from its left counterpart, this chamber presents a triangular form from the anterior perspective, enveloping the left chamber. Viewed from its apex, its right edge appears acute, defining the heart's acute margin. In cross-section, this organ resembles a crescent. As a key component of the heart's quartet of chambers, it resides within a pericardial sac, its interior surface lined by serous membrane layers, with the visceral layer comprising the epicardium. Tasked with propelling oxygen-poor blood towards the lungs, deoxygenated blood enters from the right atrium, travels through the tricuspid valve into this structure, and is then ejected upwards through the pulmonary valve into the pulmonary artery for lung transport. This structure stands as the most anterior cardiac chamber, outlining the heart's inferior contour. When compared, its form diverges from the conical left chamber, curving around it and adopting a more pronounced triangular shape from the front. Nested directly behind the sternum, its curvature and location facilitate a unique crossover of outflow tracks with the left chamber, positioned anterocéphalad, illustrating a distinct spatial relationship.
relations: lungs (via pulmonary valve and pulmonary artery)

right hip.cleaned_definition: This structure in human anatomy encompasses the area where the pelvic bone meets the thigh on the right side, facilitating linkage between the torso and the lower extremities, crucial for movement and equilibrium. It is positioned at the junction of the pelvis and the right femur, where the rounded end of the femur, known as the femoral head, engages with a concave socket in the pelvis, termed the acetabulum, forming a ball-and-socket joint. This joint's design permits a vast array of motions. Composed of the femoral head, neck, and trochanters along with the pelvis, its stability is enhanced by surrounding ligaments and smooth articulation is ensured by the covering of articular cartilage. The spatial vicinity of this organ binds it closely with the pelvis and thigh, while its functionality is supported by the attachment to various muscles such as the hamstrings which originate from the pelvis and extend down the thigh, vital for motion and maintaining stability.
relations: junction of the pelvis and the right femur

right hippocampus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a component of the hippocampal formation within the temporal lobe, stretching from the amygdala at the front to the splenium of the corpus callosum at the back. Known also as Ammon's horn, it is an elongated ridge of gray matter that forms both the floor and a part of the medial wall of the inferior horns of the lateral ventricles. Appearing as an inward fold of the archicortex into the medial temporal lobe, this organ is critical to the limbic system, engaging with emotional behaviors and connected to several key areas within the brain. It resembles a seahorse in shape and is pivotal in processing emotions, memories, especially long-term storage and retrieval, spatial navigation, and forming new memories. Additionally, this organ contributes significantly to learning, movement, emotional responses, and the imagination of future scenarios. Its primary role is in the storage of declarative memories concerning facts, events, and spatial relationships. As part of the limbic system located at the cortex's edge, it connects to important parts of the brain managing emotional behavior.
relations: medial wall of the inferior horns of the lateral ventricles

right iliac vena.cleaned_definition: This structure is a crucial component of the venous system, originating as a confluence of the external iliac vein, which serves the lower limb, and the internal iliac vein, catering to the pelvis and gluteal area. Initially located medial to its accompanying artery, it proceeds to trail behind the artery as it ascends. Around the level of the fifth vertebral bone, this vein merges with its counterpart from the opposite side to form the inferior vena cava, the principal vein responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the lower extremities back to the heart. Notably, this organ exhibits a shorter and more vertically oriented profile than its left-sided counterpart and maintains close proximity to the right common iliac artery throughout its trajectory.

right iliopsoas.cleaned_definition: Located extending from the vertebral column to the proximal femur, this organ is the most substantial and robust inner hip muscle involved in activities such as walking, running, and rising from a chair. It is composed of the iliacus, psoas major, and at times the psoas minor muscles, which collectively work to flex the hip and ensure stability of the hip and lower back. This structure is vital for maintaining appropriate lumbar posture whether standing or sitting and plays a pivotal role in the motion of walking and running. It is particularly significant in supporting the coxofemoral joint, with numerous anatomical relationships established through the fascial system it is enveloped in. These fascial coverings create several connections linking it to various viscera and muscle regions. This structure attaches to the femur at the lesser trochanter, making it the prime flexor of the hip.

right internal auditory canal.cleaned_definition: Nestled within the petrous part of the temporal bone in the skull, this structure finds its beginnings at the oval-shaped opening known as the porus acusticus internus, situated within the cranial cavity. It extends laterally into the bone for about 1 cm, carrying within it the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII), the facial nerve (CN VII), the labyrinthine artery, and the vestibular ganglion. Positioned between the inner ear and the posterior cranial fossa, it plays a critical role in the auditory and vestibular systems. Its appearance as a short, slightly curved passage, with smooth and rounded edges, underscores its significance in facilitating the transmission of auditory and vestibular information.

right kidney.cleaned_definition: This organ, an essential component within the human body, plays a key role in purifying the blood from waste products and balancing electrolytes. Located in the retroperitoneal space to the right of the spine, it is positioned slightly lower than its counterpart on the left due to the liver's presence above it in the abdominal cavity. Bean-shaped and reddish-brown, this structure measures around 11 to 14 centimeters in length, 6 centimeters in width, and has a thickness of about 4 centimeters, protected by a layer of fat, muscles, and back ribs, with additional shielding provided by the perirenal fat pad. Weighing between 125 to 175 grams in males and 115 to 155 grams in females, it houses over a million nephrons, each consisting of a renal corpuscle and renal tubule. The hilum acts as the gateway for nerves, ureters, vessels, and lymphatics that supply or drain this organ. It shares close spatial relationships with the liver, intestines, and diaphragm, with the suprarenal gland perched on its superior pole. Separated from the abdominal wall muscles by a layer of fat called the paranephric fat, which lies posteriorly and posterolaterally, the vasculature within this organ boasts end arteries without collateral, necessitating the protection of any arteries or accessory arteries to avoid impairment of parenchymal function. A relatively avascular zone, known as Brodel's line, borders longitudinally from top to bottom, just rear to the convex lateral boundary.

right lacrimal gland.cleaned_definition:
This exocrine gland, nestled above the eyeball in the anterior segment of the upper outer orbit, plays a crucial role in secreting tear fluid. This secretion is a watery fluid, isotonic to plasma, and serves as the aqueous layer of a multilayered tear film, providing lubrication, protection, and nutrients to the conjunctiva and cornea. It is comprised of two interconnected sections: the predominately larger orbital section and the lesser palpebral section. Together with its network of ducts, it constitutes the lacrimal apparatus. Sized roughly like an almond, this structure spans about 2cm and consists of cells that generate proteins and electrolytes, thereby drawing water through osmosis. Its primary blood supply comes from the ophthalmic artery, through the lacrimal artery branch, and receives its innervation from the parasympathetic lacrimatory nucleus of the facial nerve, based in the pons.

Situated in the anterior superolateral orbit, within the lacrimal fossa—a depression in the orbital plate of the frontal bone—its position is strategic. The superior boundary is the zygomatic process of the frontal bone, anteriorly bounded by the orbital septum, with orbital fat to the posterior, and the lateral rectus muscle providing the inferolateral boundary.
relations: nestled in (anterior part of the upper outer aspect)

right lens.cleaned_definition: This structure, a crucial element of the eye, is nestled behind the iris and ahead of the vitreous body. Its shape is ellipsoid and biconvex, similar to an elongated sphere, measuring about 10 mm across and 4 mm from front to back in adults. Transparent and flexible, it resembles a deflated ball, enabling it to adjust shape for precise focusing on the retina. Composed of a smooth, transparent lens capsule, the lens epithelium, and elongated, thin lens fibers that constitute the majority of its mass, its transparent nature is vital. This organ’s fibers are meticulously organized and interconnected through cellular gap junctions, a feature crucial for maintaining transparency. Furthermore, an extensive cytoskeleton within the fibers preserves the organ's specific shape and configuration. Positioned strategically, it collaborates with surrounding structures like the cornea, iris, and pupil to bend light directly onto the retina.

right lung.cleaned_definition: This organ, one of two primary respiratory structures in the human body, is found in the thoracic cavity's right half, adjacent to the mediastinum. Its conical shape encompasses a narrow top, extending to a broad, concave base perched on the diaphragm's convex surface. Comprising three lobes—superior, middle, and inferior—separated by oblique and horizontal fissures, it resembles an elephant's ears in shape. Suspended by the root, a hub for entering and exiting structures, its medial side remains in proximity to vital mediastinal components. Typically, in a healthy state, it displays a pinkish-gray hue and varies in length with respiratory phases, weighing approximately 2.2 pounds. Its development progresses through pseudoglandular, canalicular, terminal sac, and alveolar stages. Occupying space from the backbone to the chest's front and from the lower trachea to the diaphragm, it maintains precise spatial relations with surrounding structures, notably the sternum anteriorly, vertebrae posteriorly, and its concave diaphragmatic surface aligns with the diaphragm's dome, elevated on this side due to the liver's position.

right lung lower lobe.cleaned_definition: In human anatomy, the section of interest is the third division located at the base of the right lung, divided into three distinct sections. This part is conical, with its narrow top extending upwards and a broad, concave bottom sitting on the diaphragm's convexity. It notably receives its supply from a specific bronchus and is further segmented by bronchopulmonary segments, each fed by segmental bronchi, playing a crucial role in gas exchange through structures like alveoli and bronchioles. This section is anteriorly adjacent to the sternum and posteriorly to the vertebra. Its diaphragmatic side is shaped to accommodate the diaphragm's dome, particularly elevated on the right due to the liver's position beneath it. Unlike its left counterpart, this area is located by specific lung fissures, emphasizing the lung's asymmetrical anatomy.

right lung middle lobe.cleaned_definition: This structure is a significant anatomical component, nestled between the superior and inferior segments of its larger organ. Distinguished by its unique placement, it contributes to the trilobed configuration, offering a distinct and asymmetrical appearance. This organ is comprised of three segments: the upper, this structure, and the lower. Air is supplied via its own branch of the bronchial tree, extending into smaller bronchioles. Situated within close proximity to the heart, trachea, esophagus, and numerous lymph nodes, this structure is slightly larger on one side due to its division by the mediastinum. It hangs from the mediastinum by the lung root, an assembly of structures entering and leaving this vital organ.

right lung upper lobe.cleaned_definition: This structure in human anatomy plays a pivotal role in the respiratory system, being one of three lobes of its organ, delineated by two fissures - horizontal and oblique. It extends from the apex, the organ's pointed top, broadening laterally with a curvature that matches the ribcage's interior. Medially, it presents a concave profile with notches for the trachea, esophagus, and major blood vessels. The superior lobar bronchus serves this organ, channeling air through its tertiary bronchi to each bronchopulmonary segment. These segments house numerous bronchioles, branching into terminal bronchioles that terminate in alveoli clusters. Spatially, it lies above the horizontal and oblique fissures, distancing it from the organ's other lobes. Suspended by the lung root from the mediastinum, its medial aspects are adjacent to various mediastinal structures.
relations: major blood vessels of the mediastinum

right mandible.cleaned_definition: This structure, the largest and strongest bone of the facial skeleton, forms the lower jaw and accommodates the lower teeth. It takes a horseshoe shape, positioned beneath the maxilla and serving as the only movable skull bone. Its curved body and vertical rami create a symmetrical design reminiscent of a horseshoe, with its body featuring two distinct surfaces and borders. The outer or external surface exhibits specific characteristics, and the transition from body to rami occurs at the gonial angles on either side. Shaped like a U, it projects in an anteroposterior direction, where the body transitions to the rami at the gonial angles, which then extend upwards towards the cranial base articulation points. The body's superior border holds 16 tooth sockets, while the inferior base serves as the attachment point for several muscles, including the digastric muscle. Residing at the bottom of the face, it allows for a wide range of jaw movements through its articulation with the temporal bones at the temporomandibular joints, contributing significantly to chewing, speaking, and facial expressions. This organ is also anchored to muscles crucial for facial gestures and oral functions, contrasting movements with the upper jaw.

right mastoid process.cleaned_definition: This pyramid-shaped bony protrusion found at the skull's posterior base is located just posterior to the ear, serving as an attachment point for various head and neck muscles. It exhibits a conical form and features a marked groove on its medial aspect, housing air-filled cavities known as mastoid air cells. These cells are notably larger and more irregular towards the top and front, becoming smaller closer to the bottom part of this structure. Positioned immediately behind the external acoustic meatus and beside the styloid process, this smooth, conical bone projection affords an anchorage site for significant muscles like the sternocleidomastoid and the splenius capitis.

right middle ear.cleaned_definition:
This structure in human anatomy is identified as the area medial to the eardrum and distal to the cochlea's oval window, positioned within the inner ear. It is recognized for its biconcave lens shape, although, in detail, it resembles a six-sided prism more closely. Within, it harbors the auditory ossicles comprising the malleus, incus, and stapes which are instrumental in transmitting sound from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear through vibration transfer. Positioned within the temporal bone, it is bounded by the tympanic membrane, acting as a demarcation from the outer ear, characterized by a roughly 8-10 mm diameter, shaping into a flattened cone. The tympanic cavity contains not just the ossicles but also specific muscles and nerves, creating a complex network of spatial relations with its surrounding anatomy.

right middle ear eustachian tube bone ov.cleaned_definition: This structure is a canal connecting the middle ear to the nasopharynx, positioned at an angle of approximately 35 degrees in adults, descending posteroanteriorly and lateromedially. It spans roughly 31-38 mm in humans and is bifurcated into a bony and a cartilaginous part, enveloped by a mucous membrane. The bony section, occupying one-third of its length at about 12 mm, passes through the petrous part of the temporal bone. In contrast, the remaining 24 mm are cartilaginous and closer to the nasal and pharyngeal areas. This organ's mucosal lining extends into the middle ear, equipped with cilia to facilitate mucous drainage into the pharynx. The narrow segment near the ear, known as the isthmus, is the starting point for potential obstructions that could lead to chronic ear conditions. Muscles such as the tensor veli palatini and levator veli palatini, found around the soft palate, are essential for its opening during activities like swallowing.
relations: petrous part of the temporal bone
mucosal lining of the middle ear

right middle ear vestibule semicircular.cleaned_definition:
This structure, part of the vestibular system within the inner ear, belongs to a trio of looped, curved entities named for their positioning: lateral (horizontal), anterior (superior), and posterior. It is placed almost perpendicular to the other two, with its loop arching horizontally backward and sideways for a span of 12 to 15 mm. Its ampulla is near the vestibule's upper and lateral edge, adjacent to the oval window, and it opens close to the anterior canal's ampulla, while its other end emerges at the vestibule's upper and rear portion. Its alignment is virtually parallel with the lateral canal of the opposite ear, making this structure the shortest among its counterparts.

This organ aids in maintaining equilibrium and orientation through the endolymph fluid it encases, which mobilizes hair cells to detect head movements during rotational acceleration. The ampullated end, or ampulla, harbors the crista ampullaris, composed of mechanoreceptor hair cells.

right optic nerve.cleaned_definition:
This structure, also known as cranial nerve II, plays a pivotal role in the visual system by facilitating the transmission of visual information to the brain's vision centers through electrical impulses. It is part of the central nervous system and appears as a cylindrical bundle, originating from the posterior aspect of the eyeball, specifically about 2 mm medial to its posterior pole, extending towards the suprasellar space located in the middle cranial fossa. Comprising roughly 1 million myelinated axons from the ganglion cells of the retina, its length typically spans between 35 mm and 55 mm but can vary. This organ begins at the optic disk, a 1.5 mm diameter structure at the eye's rear, and travels intracranially to the brain's underside, contributing to an X-shaped formation known as the optic chiasm. Here, around half of its fibers proceed ipsilaterally, while the others cross over, joining contralateral fibers, which is vital for binocular vision.

Covered by three meningeal layers and myelinated by oligodendrocytes, this structure is a conduit for visual signals from the optic chiasm to the lateral geniculate body on the corresponding side, acting as a part of the visual pathway. It is indispensable for sight, with damage potentially leading to various visual disorders.
relations: the posterior part of the eyeball.
the posterior pole of the eyeball.
the suprasellar space in the middle cranial fossa.

right posterior eyeball.cleaned_definition: This structure, found within the facial skeleton's bony orbit, has a spheroidal shape with a slight anterior bulge. Comprising three main layers - fibrous, vascular, and inner - its essential function in vision is anchored by the retina within the inner layer. The retina, a metabolically active nerve tissue layer filled with millions of photoreceptors, plays a critical role in receiving and processing visual stimuli. The protective outer shell, known as the sclera, is made up of dense fibrous tissue, encompassing most of the organ and providing attachment sites for eye-muscle movements. This structure is also filled with a transparent, gel-like substance called vitreous humor, maintaining its shape. Spatially, it has significant connections, notably with the optic nerve (CN II), facilitating the transition of visual information to the brain for processing. Encased in the bony orbit, it gains protection and structural support.

right posterior inferior segment of live.cleaned_definition: This structure is a specific area within the liver, which itself is located in the upper right-hand side of the abdominal cavity, below the diaphragm and superior to the stomach, right kidney, and intestines. This area forms part of the larger right lobe, one of the liver’s two primary sections. The liver, mostly wrapped in visceral peritoneum except for its superior posterior part known as the bare area, extends from the fifth intercostal space to the right costal margin. Its general appearance is prism-like or wedge-shaped, with its base facing rightwards and its apex pointing left, exhibiting a pinkish-brown color and a soft, highly vascular, and easily damaged texture. This organ's associations are notably with the right kidney and the inferior vena cava. Through the right coronary and right triangular ligaments descending posteriorly towards the right kidney and connecting to the retroperitoneum, this area of the liver is held in place within the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The inferior vena cava (IVC) is notably positioned close to this organ through IVC ligaments, which are extensive membranous tissue extending from this area and the caudate lobe to help in anchoring. In the undersurface of the liver, the IVC lies within the mentioned bare area. Additionally, the gastrohepatic ligament, connecting to the ligamentum venosum, demarcates the traditionally defined right and left liver lobes on their posterior aspect.
relations: upper right-hand portion of the abdominal cavity
attached to (via right coronary and right triangular ligaments)

right posterior superior segment of live.cleaned_definition: Situated in the upper right abdomen and stretching across to the mid and left upper abdomen, this specific area of the liver showcases unique characteristics. The liver itself is nestled in the upper right quadrant of the abdominal cavity, directly under the diaphragm and atop the stomach, right kidney, and intestines, making it easily accessible for examination. Shaped roughly like a prism or wedge, it presents a pinkish-brown hue, a soft consistency, and is rich in blood vessels, making it prone to damage. The structure of the liver is intricate, divided into 2 main lobes which are further segmented into 8 parts comprising approximately 1,000 smaller lobes or lobules. These lobules connect to ducts that eventually merge into the common hepatic duct, responsible for transporting bile to the gallbladder and duodenum. This area, in particular, is demarcated by significant relations with nearby anatomical structures. It lies in close proximity to the right hepatic vein, which separates the right posterior and anterior sectors. The right coronary and right triangular ligaments also play a crucial role, extending posteriorly and caudally towards the right kidney, thus securing it to the retroperitoneum. Furthermore, its superior posterior aspect is highlighted by a bare area where both the diaphragm and the inferior vena cava are present, emphasizing its spatial relevance within the body.
relations: attached to (via right coronary and right triangular ligaments)

right rib.cleaned_definition:
Located as a part of the rib cage, this structure is a long, curved bone that serves a protective role for the chest cavity, housing organs such as the lungs and heart. It connects to the thoracic vertebrae at the back and ends at the front as cartilage, which articulates with the sternum. The shaft of this bone is characterized by its thin, flat, and curved nature, with its inner surface being concave, featuring a costal groove that safeguards and guides the neurovascular bundle. The head displays a wedge shape with two articular facets, designed for joint formation with the thoracic vertebrae, demarcated by a crest. This bone is thin, flat, and presents with a curve, holding a specific groove that supports essential neurovascular structures. It forms part of the axial skeleton, emphasizing its role in the thoracic protective cage, facilitating articulation with both the vertebral column and the sternum through its anterior cartilaginous termination. Moreover, its costal angle signifies a critical site for deep back muscle attachment.

right rib 1.cleaned_definition: This structure is positioned at the top among the twelve ribs, serving as a critical marker at the edge of the superior thoracic aperture. Its body, or shaft, is characterized by a thin, flat, and curved design, with the curvature becoming notably distinct at the costal angle where this bone turns anterolaterally. The internal side is hollowed, featuring a costal groove that shelters and guides the neurovascular bundle. This organ concludes with a socket for the costal cartilage, facilitating its joint with the sternum. The head presents a wedge shape, equipped with two articular facets divided by a bone wedge, known as the crest of the head. The more substantial facet connects with the superior costal facet of its matching vertebral body, and the smaller facet joins with the inferior costal facet of the same vertebral body. It links with the vertebral column at the back and extends anteriorly as cartilage to connect with the sternum, constituting a primary element of the thoracic cage and delineating one of the edges of the superior thoracic aperture.

right rib 10.cleaned_definition: This structure is a component of the thoracic cage that safeguards the heart and lungs by encircling them within a bony framework. It has a slender, flat, and curved body, accentuated at the costal angle where it turns anterolaterally. The internal side is concave, featuring a costal groove that secures and guides the neurovascular bundle. This organ concludes with a socket for the costal cartilage, enabling a connection with the sternum. It articulates with the directly corresponding vertebral bone and the one above it. Unlike the last two false ribs, which do not connect to the sternum and end within the lateral abdominal wall muscles, this structure indirectly bonds with the sternum through the elevation of its costal cartilage to that of the rib above.

right rib 12.cleaned_definition: This structure is among the set of twelve pairs found in the human anatomy, distinguished by its lack of attachment to the sternum, instead ending within the lateral abdominal wall's musculature. Its body is characterized by a slender, curved shape, with a significant bend marked at the costal angle as it turns anterolaterally. The internal side features a concavity accommodating a costal groove, crucial for protecting the neurovascular bundle that travels within. The terminus is designed to articulate via a small costal cartilage yet does not connect to the sternum, defining it as a floating rib.

right rib 2.cleaned_definition: Located in the upper thoracic region within the chest area known as the thorax, it resides between the first and third ribs, contributing to the rib cage that guards the thoracic cavity's vital organs. This structure's shaft is slender, flat, and bends prominently at the costal angle, where it turns anterolaterally. Its inner surface is hollowed, hosting the costal groove that shields and directs the neurovascular bundle. The wedge-shaped head features two articular facets divided by a bone crest. The larger facet connects with the matching vertebral body's superior costal facet, and the smaller with the vertebra above's inferior costal facet. Comprising a head, neck, and body, its body is thin, flat, curved, with a concave interior and a costal groove for neurovascular bundle protection. The body concludes with a notch for costal cartilage, enabling sternum articulation. Positioned between the first and third ribs, it is an integral part of the rib cage safeguarding thoracic organs. It connects posteriorly with the vertebral column and ends anteriorly in cartilage, facilitating sternum connectivity. The costal angle also signifies where certain deep back muscles attach to the ribs.

right rib 3.cleaned_definition:
Located on the right side of the thoracic region, this structure is one of the twelve pairs of bones composing the protective rib cage. Its shaft is characterized by a thin, flat, and curved form, with its curvature most pronounced at its costal angle, where it turns anterolaterally. The internal side presents a concave shape, incorporating a costal groove that safeguards and guides the neurovascular bundle. The shaft culminates in a receptacle for the costal cartilage, facilitating its articulation with the sternum.

The head of this bone presents a wedge shape, outfitted with two articular facets divided by a bone wedge, known as the crest of the head. The larger facet connects with the superior costal facet on the corresponding vertebral body, while the smaller one engages with the inferior facet of the same vertebra.

Spatially, it articulates with the vertebral column at its posterior end and concludes anteriorly in cartilage, specifically the costal cartilage, which secures an independent attachment to the sternum.

right rib 4.cleaned_definition:
This structure is a part of the rib cage, serving as a protective component for the thorax. Its shaft is slender, flattened, and notably curved, with the curve being most apparent at the costal angle where it veers anterolaterally. The inner surface is concave, featuring a costal groove that safeguards and guides the neurovascular bundle. Its termination includes a socket for the costal cartilage to connect with the sternum, facilitating its articulation.

The head of this rib is wedge-shaped, housing two articular facets divided by a bony crest. The larger facet articulates with the corresponding superior costal facet of the vertebral body, and the smaller one with the vertebra above. This rib connects independently to the sternum, integral to the bony thorax, safeguarding internal organs and aiding in respiratory mechanics by facilitating lung expansion through chest movement.

It articulates posteriorly with the vertebral column and ends anteriorly in cartilage to meet the sternum.

right rib 5.cleaned_definition:
This structure, belonging to the fifth position on the thoracic right side, forms an essential part of the protective cage for the thorax. Its situated region is the thoracic area, specifically enhancing the chest cavity's safeguarding, sheltering significant organs. With a characteristic thin, flat, and curved body that notably bends at its costal angle, this organ also features a concave internal surface adorned with a costal groove, safeguarding and guiding the neurovascular bundle. Its structure comprises a head, neck, and body, where the head, of a wedge shape, presents two articulating facets divided by bone for connections with the vertebrae. This bone extends into cartilage anteriorly, allowing articulation with the sternum, further playing a critical part in encasing the heart and lungs.

Relation: provides protection for, Anatomical structure: heart and lungs
Relation: articulates posteriorly with, Anatomical structure: vertebral column
Relation: terminates anteriorly as, Anatomical structure: costal cartilage
Relation: allows articulation with, Anatomical structure: sternum

right rib 6.cleaned_definition: It, known as the sixth member of the rib cage on the right side, acts as a protective feature for the thorax. This organ is positioned to the right of the thoracic cavity, stretching from the vertebral column to where it meets the sternum. Its body, or shaft, is characterized by a slender, flat, and curvaceous form, particularly pronounced at the costal angle, the point where it veers anterolaterally. The inner surface showcases a concavity housing the costal groove, serving as both protection and a conduit for the accompanying neurovascular bundle. The termination of this part includes a recess to hold the costal cartilage, facilitating its junction with the sternum. Comprising a head, neck, and body, with the head featuring a wedge shape and dual articular facets divided by a sliver of bone for articulation with both the direct and adjacent vertebrae above. The primary role of this structure is to encase the lungs and heart within the rib cage, attributing significant protection to these crucial organs. Its connection points include posteriorly with the vertebral column and anteriorly terminating as cartilage, which merges with the costal cartilage for sternum articulation.
relations: located on the right side of

right rib 7.cleaned_definition: This structure, located in the thoracic region, is part of the protective cage encasing the thorax, safeguarding the lungs and heart. It is characterized by its thin, flat, and curved shaft, which notably bends at the costal angle, turning anterolaterally. Its internal surface showcases a concavity, housing a costal groove that safeguards and guides the neurovascular bundle. This organ culminates in a cup-shaped end for the costal cartilage, enabling junctions with the sternum. The head of this structure is wedge-shaped, presenting two articular facets divided by a bone crest. The larger facet connects with the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body, while the smaller one links with the above vertebra. Moreover, its costal groove serves as a protective conduit for the neurovascular bundle. It independently joins the sternum via costal cartilage at the front, engaging with the vertebral column at the rear. Its anterior termination as cartilage contributes to the protection of internal thoracic structures and aids ventilation by facilitating chest expansion for lung inflation.

right rib 8.cleaned_definition: Part of the protective thoracic cage, it articulates with the vertebral column at the back and extends forward as cartilage, referred to as costal cartilage. This organ's body, or shaft, presents as thin, flat, and notably curved, especially at the costal angle where it turns anterolaterally. Its internal surface is concave, featuring a costal groove that provides a protective path for the neurovascular bundle. The body concludes with a space designed for the costal cartilage, enabling articulation with the sternum. The head bears a wedge shape with two articular facets divided by a bone wedge. These facets connect with the directly corresponding vertebra and the one above it. Classified as a false rib, it indirectly attaches to the sternum. Specifically, it connects to the costal cartilage of the seventh rib instead of directly attaching to the sternum, distinguishing it along with ribs 9 and 10. These false ribs conclude within the muscles of the lateral abdominal wall, never directly attaching to the sternum.

right rib 9.cleaned_definition: This structure is positioned in the thoracic area on the right side, nestled between two others, connecting to the thoracic vertebrae at the back, and extending forward to its costal cartilage. It features a slender, curved shaft characterized by a notable bend at the costal angle, where it shifts direction towards the front and side. The underside harbors a groove safeguarding a neurovascular bundle, leading toward the anterior end where a depression awaits the costal cartilage, facilitating its junction with the sternum. Comprising a head, neck, and body, its head displays a unique shape with dual articular facets divided by bone, designed for articulation with the corresponding and the immediately superior vertebra. A notable tubercle along its length plays a part in its relationship with deep back muscles, offering them a place of attachment and playing a pivotal role in respiratory mechanics by moving to allow for lung expansion.

right submandibular gland.cleaned_definition: Located within the anterior part of the submandibular triangle, these glands are nestled beneath the inferior body of the mandible, flanked anteriorly by the anterior belly of the digastric muscle, and posteriorly by its posterior belly. They exhibit elongated, flattened hook-like forms, distinguished by superficial and deep sections. Their arrangement allows them to encircle the mylohyoid muscle. The smaller, deep portion extends anteriorly towards the sublingual gland's posterior end, surrounded by various muscles and neurovascular structures. Inferolateral to these organs is the mylohyoid, with the hyoglossus and styloglossus positioned medially. The gland comprises superficial and deep lobes, divided by the mylohyoid muscle, and is closely associated with the mylohyoid, hyoglossus, and styloglossus muscles, aside from the lingual nerve, deep lingual vein, and hypoglossal nerve. The lingual nerve crosses over the deep part, whilst the deep lingual vein and hypoglossal nerve run beneath it. Wharton's duct facilitates drainage into the buccal cavity, its path intricately woven amongst the lingual nerve, deep lingual vein, and hypoglossal nerve.

right temporal lobe.cleaned_definition: This structure is an essential part of the human brain, contributing to sensory processing, memory storage, and emotional reaction. Situated in both cerebral hemispheres, it collaborates with various brain regions for the efficient handling and moving of information. Anterior to the hippocampus, this region presses into the tip of the temporal horn and is rich in subcortical white matter, featuring prominent bundles like the anterior commissure, arcuate fasciculus, inferior longitudinal fasciculus, uncinate fasciculus, and Meyer's loop of the geniculocalcarine tract. It forms approximately 16% of the human cerebral cortex's volume. Extending above towards the Sylvian fissure and behind up to an imaginary boundary, the lateral parietotemporal line, it distinguishes itself from the adjacent inferior parietal lobule and the occipital lobe. Positioned below the parietal lobe and beneath the lateral fissure, this organ is closer to the brain's base. Integral components such as Wernicke's area, Broca's area, and parts of the limbic system, which play a role in emotional regulation, are nestled within it. In spatial context, it is separated by the lateral fissure from the frontal and parietal lobes, in addition to the occipital lobe, thereby facilitating interactions across various brain regions. It plays a pivotal role in language comprehension, memory formation, facial and object recognition, alongside auditory and visual signal processing.
relations: subcortical white matter (including anterior commissure, arcuate fasciculus, inferior longitudinal fasciculus, uncinate fasciculus, and Meyer's loop of the geniculocalcarine tract)

right temporomandibular joint.cleaned_definition: This structure, essential for jaw movement and enabling crucial functions like chewing and speaking, is a bilateral synovial formation found between the temporal bone of the skull and the mandible beneath. Specifically, its upper portion consists of the temporal bone, featuring the mandibular fossa and articular tubercle, while its lower aspect mainly comprises the mandibular condyle. Located just anterior to the ear's tragus, on the face's lateral side, it operates as a hinge-type synovial joint, linking the mandible to the skull, and acting together as a unit. The joint surfaces are fibrocartilaginous, never in direct contact due to an interposed articular disc dividing the joint into dual cavities, each with its synovial membrane. Furthermore, the disc itself, being biconcave, has thicker borders around its anterior and posterior, resulting in a thin intermediate zone. This anatomic design ensures the bones' articular surfaces, coated by fibrocartilage instead of hyaline cartilage, avoid direct contact, enabling smooth jaw movement.
relations: the temporal bone of the skull and the mandible.
involves (fibrocartilaginous surfaces and an articular disc between)
the mandibular condyle and the articular surface of the temporal bone.
the articular surfaces of the bones.

right thyroid.cleaned_definition: This vital endocrine organ, found in the anterior neck beneath the skin and lower than the voice box, is butterfly-shaped, consisting of two lobes joined by a slender tissue band called the thyroid isthmus. The lobes are positioned around the cricoid cartilage and the upper tracheal rings, providing a unique shape. It shares space with the infrahyoid muscles, notably the sternothyroid and the superior belly of the omohyoid. Blood flow to this structure is mainly from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries, with the possible addition of the thyroidea ima artery. These vessels extensively interconnect, both on the same side and across the midline. This structure is crucial for producing thyroid hormone and calcitonin, which are essential for metabolism regulation, growth, and maintaining electrolyte levels such as calcium. Situated in the midline of the anterior neck, this organ's proximity to nearby anatomy is significant for surgical considerations.
relations: superior belly of the omohyoid muscle

right vestibule semicircular canal.cleaned_definition: This structure is an integral component of the inner ear's vestibular system, which is pivotal for maintaining equilibrium and posture. It forms one of the trio of semicircular canals, each laid out at approximately right angles to the others. Commonly referred to as the lateral or horizontal canal, it holds the distinction of being the briefest among them. Oriented about 30 degrees from the horizontal axis, it extends horizontally backward and to the side. Its terminal segment expands into the ampulla, where it connects with the vestibule. Within the ampulla resides the crista ampullaris, a gathering of mechanoreceptor cells equipped with hair cells, capable of sensing head motions such as nods, shakes, and tilts. Positioned adjacently to the stapes and cochlea, its ampullary end is near the vestibule's upper and lateral angle, barely above the oval window. This aligns closely with the anterior semicircular canal's ampullary end. Its other extremity opens towards the upper and rear portion of the vestibule, almost aligning the lateral canals of both ears in the same plane. This curved, looped configuration incorporates the crista ampullaris for detecting rotational accelerations across the horizontal plane.
relations: ampullated end of the anterior semicircular canal
ends with a dilation (ampulla) that opens into

sacrum.cleaned_definition:
This structure is a large, triangular bone at the base of the vertebral column, located in the upper, back part of the pelvic cavity, nestled between the two wings of the pelvis. This bone comes into being by the fusion of five specific vertebrae, typically finalized between the ages of 18 and 30. The side projections, known as alae (wings), join with the ilium at the L-shaped sacroiliac joints. Its top portion connects with the last lumbar vertebra (L5), and the bottom portion with the coccyx (tailbone) through the sacral and coccygeal cornua.

Occupying the posterior third of the pelvic girdle, it showcases an inverted triangular, concave shape. Comprising a base, apex, and four surfaces, the base of this organ aligns superiorly with the fifth lumbar vertebra, while the apex interacts with the coccyx. The lateral parts feature auricular surfaces for articulation with the ilium. Its front and back surfaces offer sites for the attachment of pelvic ligaments and muscles.

This structure not only forms the posterior pelvic wall, enhancing pelvis strength and stability but also concludes with the coccyx, supporting pelvic organs mildly. At its broad superior end, this bone creates the fibrocartilaginous lumbosacral joint with the fifth lumbar vertebra above it and tapers down to form the fibrocartilaginous sacrococcygeal joint with the coccyx. Laterally, it forms the sacroiliac joints with the ilium of the hip bones, cementing the pelvis's rigidity. The anterior surface's concavity increases the pelvic cavity space.

This organ also exhibits differences between sexes; it is broader, shorter, and more curved at the top in females, whereas in males, it is longer, narrower, and flatter.
relations: connects with (via the sacral and coccygeal cornua)
lumbosacral joint (with the fifth lumbar vertebra)
