Relation: projects to, Anatomical structure: anterior amygdaloid area and various amygdaloid nuclei
relations: ventromedial nucleus (posterior part) of the thalamus
dorsal aspect of the lateral and central amygdaloid nuclei

left insula posterior short gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is found deep within the brain, nestled in the lateral sulcus which divides the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal one. It's part of the insula, which holds a configuration consisting of a long gyrus posteriorly, complemented by two posterior long gyri divided by the post-central insular sulcus. It belongs to the section of the insula that transitions from anterior agranular to posterior granular regions, featuring a noteworthy composition of von Economo neurons among the typical pyramidal neurons in its fifth layer. This organ is intricately linked with the secondary somatosensory cortex, engaging in reciprocal connections and drawing specialized input from specific regions of the thalamus involved in processing a range of homeostatic and sensory information.
relations: frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe
the posterior part of the insula

left lateral remainder occipital lobe.cleaned_definition: Situated at the brain's rear, behind the temporal and parietal lobes and beneath the occipital bone, this structure is involved in visual processing. It displays a triangular form, marked by a network of gyri and sulci on its surface. Including the primary and secondary visual cortices, it comprises neurons among other cell types. This organ is delineated from the temporal lobe by an imaginary plane aligning with the parietooccipital sulcus, rests beneath the occipital bone, and is cushioned above the tentorium cerebelli, which demarcates it from the cerebellum. Its anatomical position and makeup are vital for its role in visual interpretation.
relations: temporal lobe (via an imaginary plane in line with the parietooccipital sulcus)

left lateral ventricle excluding tempora.cleaned_definition: This structure, a crucial part of the brain's ventricular system, is integral to the circulation and containment of cerebrospinal fluid. It is located within the cerebral hemisphere, extending across the occipital, frontal, and parietal lobes with a distinctive C-shape. This organ consists of a body and an atrium, with extensions into the frontal and occipital lobes. It is bordered by the septum pellucidum and the fornix medially, and its floor is primarily the superior surface of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus, between which lie the stria terminalis and thalamostriate veins. It contains parts of the choroid plexus responsible for cerebrospinal fluid production. This organ's intricate relationships with various other brain structures, including the thalamus, caudate nucleus, fornix, septum pellucidum, hippocampus, amygdala, and deep cerebral white matter, are crucial for understanding its role and function within the ventricular system.

left lateral ventricle temporal horn.cleaned_definition: This structure, a component of the brain's ventricular system, is crucial for the containment of cerebrospinal fluid. It is found within the temporal lobe, standing out as the most significant part of the ventricles' horns. Its C-shaped cavity mirrors the hemisphere's shape, with its extension reaching into the temporal lobe. The appearance of this organ is marked by a prominent feature in the floor, closely related to the human hippocampal formation. The roof encompasses fibers from the temporal lobe. Moreover, relevant anatomical connection includes its association with the stria terminalis and the caudate's tail along the medial border, whereas the hippocampus and its related structures form the medial wall and floor.
relations: stria terminalis and tail of the caudate

left lingual gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure, positioned on the medial aspect of the occipital lobe along its inferomedial surface, resembles the shape of a tongue and is involved in the visual processing of letters and complex images. Known for its tongue-like appearance, it is integral for interpreting visual information, including aspects of human faces, and plays a role in the memorization and recall of such images in working memory. This organ, forming the occipital part of the medial occipitotemporal gyrus, is critical for distinguishing changes in the shape of simple rectangular targets. It is nourished by specific blood vessels and is closely situated to other significant structures within the brain, enhancing its role in visual information processing.

left medial orbital gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure, a distinct part of the human brain, resides within the frontal lobe's inferior or orbital surface. It's categorized as one among four orbital gyri that are delineated by a clear H-shaped orbital sulcus, segregating it into medial, anterior, lateral, and posterior sections. Directly next to the olfactory sulcus, which accommodates the olfactory tract, this area is immediately adjacent to the straight gyrus. This straight gyrus further extends into continuity with the superior frontal gyrus located on the brain's medial aspect. Positioned on the anterior cranial fossa's floor, it takes on a concave formation above the orbital plate belonging to the frontal bone. As a vital component of the frontal lobe, which claims a third of the cerebral hemisphere extending from the frontal pole to the central sulcus, it exemplifies the intricate structure and relationship dynamics pivotal to brain functionality.
relations: inferior surface of the frontal lobe
orbital plate of the frontal bone

left middle and inferior temporal gyrus.cleaned_definition: Situated in the human brain, these structures occupy a critical position on the temporal lobe, nestled between other significant regions. The one situated somewhat above the ears is sandwiched by the superior temporal sulcus on its upper boundary and the inferior temporal sulcus below. Its counterpart, directly beneath it, is delineated from below by the occipital-temporal sulcus, which it shares a border with the fusiform gyrus. In appearance, these ridges form a notable aspect of the brain's lateral surface, extending towards the base of the temporal lobe. Functionally, they are integral to a plethora of cognitive functions, including the understanding of semantic memory, language, visual perception, and the synthesis of multisensory information. Notably, the area above the ears is key in processing distances, facial recognition, emotional responses to audio-visual stimuli, and language comprehension. The section at the bottom plays a substantial role in visual analytics within the ventral stream and is crucial for certain types of mental imagery. Collectively, they are central to the interpretation of facial information and are pivotal components of the brain's system for identifying objects within the visual field.
relations: superior temporal gyrus and inferior temporal gyrus

left middle frontal gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure occupies a segment of the frontal lobe, accounting for approximately one-third of its volume. Situated ahead of the precentral gyrus, it is framed by the inferior frontal sulcus at the bottom, superior frontal sulcus at the top, and precentral sulcus at the rear. Characterized by its spindle-like shape, it is more accurately described as a region within the frontal gyrus rather than an independent gyrus. Visually, it forms a notable bulge on the brain's surface, nestled between the superior and inferior frontal sulci as a prominent part of the frontal lobe's lateral aspect. Functionally, it plays a crucial role in the neural networks responsible for working memory and spatial processing, especially its superior portion in the dominant side. Spatially, it is located in front of the precentral gyrus, with significant boundaries marked by key sulci, and lies on the lateral face of the frontal lobe, demarcated from the parietal and temporal lobes by the central and lateral sulci, respectively.
relations: part of the lateral side of

left nucleus accumbens.cleaned_definition: This organ is a crucial component of the ventral striatum, playing significant roles in the regulation of motivation, affect, and reward through its intimate connections to the limbic system. Occupying a space between the caudate and putamen in the basal forebrain, it includes two distinct parts: the shell, forming its outer region, and the core, sitting internally. The outer region, or the shell, is notably part of the extended amygdala at its most rostral point. Besides its primary structure, this structure is distinguished by its rich network of connections, especially with the ventral tegmental area, highlighting its integral position in the brain's reward circuit. Regarding its spatial relations, it nestles between the caudate and putamen, marking it as an essential part of both the basal ganglia and the ventral striatum. This alignment not only underlines its relevance to the limbic system but also its interconnections with the ventral tegmental area, the basal ganglia, and the extended amygdala, affirming its wide-reaching influence within the brain.

left optic radiation.cleaned_definition: This structure is an essential component of the visual pathway in the human brain. It consists of nerve fibers that transmit visual information from the lateral geniculate body to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Located in both hemispheres of the brain, it stretches caudally and laterally, ending in the lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus. Blood supply to this organ comes from deep branches of the middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery. It is divided into two sections that deliver visual information to the visual cortex along the calcarine fissure. The fibers ensure that spatially adjacent retinal units remain separated, with macular fibers situated medially. Fibers from each eye extend to a similar anterior extent in Meyer's loop, with those from the contralateral eye positioned medially. Due to its critical location, there is a risk of damage during epilepsy surgery, necessitating thorough preoperative planning to minimize the risk of consequential postsurgical visual field deficits.
relations: lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus
deep branches of the middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

left parahippocampal and ambient gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is found in the medial temporal lobe, specifically positioned superior to the tentorium and wrapping anteriorly to create the uncus of the temporal lobe, while posteriorly, it extends into the appearance of the lingual gyrus. This organ covers the hippocampus on the medial side and is anteromedially close to the amygdala. Its inferolateral boundary is marked by the collateral sulcus. Another notable feature in the medial temporal lobe, distinguished by its position in the medialmost part of the anterior temporal lobe and demarcated from the fusiform gyrus by the collateral sulcus, it lies medially relative to the fusiform gyrus. It appears spindle-shaped, with a broad center tapering towards the ends, encapsulating grey matter that surrounds the hippocampus and plays a crucial role in memory processes. Additionally, this structure encompasses the medial intermediate subfield of the entorhinal cortex (Brodmann area 28), closely related to Brodmann area 34.
relations: fusiform gyrus by the collateral sulcus

left postcentral gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a pronounced ribbon of grey matter located on the lateral part of the parietal lobes, nestled between the central and postcentral sulci. It hosts the primary somatosensory cortex, a key player in processing somatic sensations like touch, pressure, temperature, and discomfort. Additionally, it is home to the secondary somatosensory cortex which contributes to integrating sensory stimuli and forming memories. Being a component of the parietal lobe and nourished by the middle cerebral artery, this structure stretches downward and forward from the cerebral hemisphere's apex to its inner facet, creating the posterior segment of the paracentral lobule. It presents a structured cortical representation, akin to a map, which reflects specific spatial activity patterns that correspond to distinct inputs. The sensory homunculus, a unique map within this region, illustrates the contralateral distribution of body parts, organizing them in a particular sequence from the outer side towards the inner side of the brain. In essence, this organ is vital for registering a variety of bodily sensations, structured in a highly organized map to reflect distinct spatial patterns corresponding to various stimuli.
relations: the lateral surface of the parietal lobes
the inner surface of the cerebral hemisphere

left posterior cingulate gyrus.cleaned_definition:
Positioned on the medial side of the cerebral hemisphere, this structure stretches from the subcallosal area in the front to the isthmus at the back. It sits atop the corpus callosum, nestled between the cingulate and corpus callosum sulci. Characterized by its extensive coverage and division into areas responsible for various functions such as viscero-motor and cognitive activities, it exhibits distinct cytoarchitectural features across its anterior and posterior sections. Additionally, it comprises grey matter and forms a crucial part of the limbic system, ensuring its involvement in a myriad of functions from movement to spatial navigation. The vascular needs of this organ are met by the precuneal artery, a derivative of the pericallosal artery. Its network extends to and from various significant brain regions, ensuring a vast array of functionalities from sensory processing to movement regulation.

left posterior temporal lobe.cleaned_definition: Situated in the human brain, this structure is essential for functions including language processing, memory, and the perception of sound and visuals. Located behind the left ear, it ranks as the brain's second largest region, trailing only behind the frontal lobe. This area reaches up to the Sylvian fissure and extends backward until the lateral parietotemporal line, delineating it from the parietal lobe's inferior parietal lobule superiorly and the occipital lobe inferiorly. The middle cranial fossa sets the anterior and inferior boundaries. Though it appears more as a region housing diverse critical structures rather than a distinct organ, its composition includes the hippocampus, the Wernicke's area, and the limbic system, among others. Moreover, the primary auditory cortex is situated at the Heschl gyri, close to the notable Sylvian fissure, distinguishing it from the frontal and parietal lobes. Above, the frontal and parietal lobes can be found, while the occipital lobe is positioned slightly behind. It is intricately connected with the brain's other regions, facilitating communication across the entire body through its linkage with the spinal cord. This region's interrelations with various brain structures underline its significance for cognitive processes such as language, memory, and perception.
relations: inferior parietal lobule of the parietal lobe

left precentral gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a significant ridge of grey matter on the posterior frontal lobe's lateral side. It is located just in front of the central sulcus, paralleling it to stretch towards the precentral sulcus. Housing the primary motor cortex, identified cytoarchitecturally as Brodmann area 4, is its primary role. Situated on the frontal lobe's lateral surface, it is demarcated anteriorly by the precentral sulcus, while the lateral sulcus forms its inferior boundary. Medially, it merges seamlessly with the paracentral lobule. Around the superior frontal sulcus's end, it curves in an omega shape, marking the motor cortex's hand area. The intersection here serves as a distinguishing landmark between the frontal and central lobes. Appearing omega-shaped, it is prominently recognized during surgical procedures through the precentral knob, marking the hand area of the motor cortex. This diagonally oriented convolution contains large Betz cells, which project axons to contralateral motor nuclei, with a somatotopical organization represented by an inverted homunculus.
relations: lateral surface of the posterior frontal lobe

left putamen.cleaned_definition: This structure is found in the forebrain and forms part of the dorsal striatum alongside the caudate nucleus. It represents the outer portion of the basal ganglia, a cluster of nuclei linked with the cerebral cortex, thalamus, and brainstem. This structure, in conjunction with the globus pallidus, constitutes the lentiform nucleus. It is intricately connected with the caudate nucleus, nucleus accumbens, and globus pallidus, collectively known as the corpus striatum. This organ plays a key role in a complex feedback loop that facilitates limb movement preparation and execution. Additionally, it is intersected by the internal capsule, a significant fiber tract, which splits the dorsal striatum. Disorders such as Parkinson's disease can impact this area, leading to involuntary muscle movements or tremors, while Huntington's disease can also affect it, resulting in jerky, unpredictable movements.

left straight gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a ridge-like elevation located on the cerebral cortex's surface, more precisely in the inferior part of the frontal lobe, alongside the longitudinal fissure. It seamlessly joins the superior frontal gyrus on the medial side. Characterized by its ridge appearance made of gray matter, this organ is critical in increasing the brain's surface area and thus enhances cognitive functions. Positioned in the anterior cranial fossa, this structure rests upon the skull's orbital plate of the frontal bone and covers a significant portion of the cerebral hemisphere, extending from the very front (frontal pole) towards the back, up to the central sulcus, which distinguishes it from the parietal lobe.
relations: orbital plate of the frontal bone

left subcallosal area.cleaned_definition: Positioned on the medial surface of the hemisphere, this small triangular structure is situated anteriorly to the subcallosal gyrus, delineated by the posterior parolfactory sulcus. It merges beneath with the olfactory trigone and connects above and in front with the cingulate gyrus, bound on the front by the anterior parolfactory sulcus. Commonly referred to as "Zuckerkandl's gyrus", it is part of the periarcheocortex alongside the parahippocampal gyrus and cingulate gyrus. Although "this structure" is seen as equivalent to the "parolfactory area" in some terminologies, it is distinguished as a separate entity in others.
relations: continuous above and in front with

left subgenual frontal cortex.cleaned_definition: Situated in the frontal lobe of the human brain, this structure is nestled in the anterior cranial fossa, resting atop the orbital plate of the frontal bone. It spans from the very front of the cerebral hemisphere to the boundary at the central sulcus. This area, forming the largest portion of the brain's lobes, integrates four main gyri, including the precentral gyrus and the three horizontal gyri: superior, middle, and inferior, the latter being segmented further into the orbital, triangular, and opercular parts. At the base, the straight gyrus and the orbital gyri are prominent. The cortex itself showcases a unique topology of ridges and valleys, referred to as gyri and sulci, designed to maximize cortical volume within the limited cranial space. This organ lies ahead of the central sulcus and above the lateral sulcus, playing pivotal roles in a variety of high-level cognitive functions, including decision-making, personality expression, and motor skills, also housing the critical Broca's area for speech.
relations: the orbital plate of the frontal bone

left substantia nigra.cleaned_definition: Situated in the midbrain, specifically behind the crus cerebri and forming an integral part of the basal ganglia's circuitry, this structure can be observed. Morphologically, it is distinguished into two regions: the larger, dorsomedial area known as the pars compacta, which showcases a dark coloration due to its high concentration of intracellular neuromelanin and predominantly houses densely packed dopaminergic neurons. Conversely, the ventral area, referred to as the pars reticulata, constitutes the second component. Despite its appearance as a continuous band in brain sections, this organ essentially comprises these two distinct segments with vastly divergent connections and roles. The majority of its cells within the pars compacta are dopaminergic neurons. Additionally, this organ facilitates connections throughout the brain, particularly within the basal ganglia network, significantly influencing movement and muscle tone through dopamine production. Its elaborate neuronal interconnections contribute to various brain functions, including learning, mood regulation, judgment, and decision-making processes.

left superior frontal gyrus.cleaned_definition: Situated in the human brain's frontal lobe, this structure is pivotal for various cognitive tasks. It resides anterior to the parietal lobe, marked off by the central sulcus, and is positioned superiorly and anteriorly relative to the temporal lobe, with the lateral sulcus or Sylvian fissure acting as a boundary. This ridge-like formation on the cerebral cortex's surface, encircled by sulci, plays a part in the frontal lobe, housing the prefrontal cortex. This area is instrumental in higher-order cognitive activities like making decisions, motivating, solving problems, planning, paying attention, alongside working memory and managing spatial information. Below this region, separated by the superior frontal sulcus, lies the middle frontal gyrus, essential for developing reading skills. This part also establishes connections with nearby frontal and opercular regions, aiding in concentration and calculations.
relations: separated by (via lateral sulcus or Sylvian fissure)

left superior parietal gyrus.cleaned_definition:
Located in the parietal lobe's posteroinferior area, this structure is essential for sensory perception, spatial cognition, and the integration of sensory data. It finds its place nestled between the frontal and occipital lobes, resting above the temporal lobe within the left cerebral hemisphere. Characterized by its ridge-like appearance of grey matter, enveloped by surrounding sulci, it is a significant section of the superior parietal lobule, renowned for its contribution to bodily or spatial awareness. Its role is pivotal in funneling visual information towards language processing centers, aiding in the comprehension of language, numbers, spatial awareness, memory recall, attentional deployment, and social cognition aspects like theory of mind. As a key component of the heteromodal association cortex, which encompasses areas involved in a myriad array of cognitive functions, it shows intricate connections with other brain regions through specific neural pathways. 

Relation: situated between, Anatomical structure: frontal and occipital lobes
Relation: located above, Anatomical structure: temporal lobe
Relation: part of, Anatomical structure: superior parietal lobule
Relation: connected to (via dorsal splenium and isthmus), Anatomical structure: corpus callosum
Relation: located posterior to, Anatomical structure: supramarginal gyrus
Relation: forms (as part of), Anatomical structure: inferior parietal lobule
Relation: known as, Anatomical structure: Brodmann area 39
relations: connected to (via dorsal splenium and isthmus)

left superior temporal gyrus anterior pa.cleaned_definition: Situated in the human brain's temporal lobe, this structure resides laterally to the head, notably above the external ear. It is encased by the lateral sulcus above and the superior temporal sulcus below, with its posterior boundary being an imaginary line stretching from the preoccipital notch to the lateral sulcus. This organ presents as a grey matter ridge on the brain's surface, bordered by fissures. As an integral part of the temporal lobe, it extends to the superior surface of the temporal lobe, thus creating the lateral sulcus's floor. Characterized by obliquely oriented ridges known as the transverse temporal gyri, this area houses the primary auditory cortex, leading to the planum temporale, which exhibits a notable size difference predominantly in men. Inside, it encompasses crucial brain structures like Brodmann areas 41 and 42, pinpointing the auditory cortex's site. The auditory cortex itself expands across the supratemporal plane within this structure, visibly delineated into Heschl's gyrus (HG), planum polare, and planum temporale, with HG stretching from the lateral aspect into the insular cortex.
relations: superior surface of the temporal lobe

left superior temporal gyrus middle part.cleaned_definition: This structure is a specified area within the temporal lobe of the human brain, positioned laterally to the head, near the area above the external ear. It is bordered by the lateral sulcus at the top, the superior temporal sulcus beneath, and an imaginary line from the preoccipital notch to the lateral sulcus at the back. Continuity is seen at its superior edge with the transverse temporal gyri, which are hidden in the lateral sulcus's floor, projecting anterolaterally from the circular sulcus encompassing the insula. This region houses vital brain structures, including Brodmann areas 41 and 42, indicative of the auditory cortex's site - a key area for sound perception. Additionally, it plays roles in evaluating distance, facial recognition, the integration of audio-visual emotional cues, and word meaning during reading activities. It lies above the superior temporal and below the inferior temporal sulcus, seamlessly integrating with the transverse temporal gyri at the superior edge. Functional and structural connectivity with distant brain parts manifests in two primary clusters: one connecting superiorly with the posterior inferior frontal gyrus and another extending to the frontal lobe's superior segments. This zone is pivotal in sound processing and supports a broad spectrum of cognitive functionalities linked to perception, recognition, and language skills.

left thalamus.cleaned_definition: Located in the brain, just above the brain stem, this structure is nestled between the cerebral cortex and the midbrain, surrounding the third ventricle. It is part of the diencephalon, emerging as one of its largest derivatives during embryonic development. Comprising two symmetrical halves, each section of this organ stretches along the anteroposterior axis, adopting an ovoid shape. Narrowest at the anterior end and widest posteriorly, its most notable features are two protuberances on the posteroventral surface. Predominantly composed of gray matter, it is segmented by a Y-shaped white matter structure known as the internal medullary lamina into three main regions: anterior, medial, and lateral. These halves are connected through the interthalamic adhesion. Functioning as a primary relay for motor, limbic, and most sensory pathways—excluding olfaction—it holds extensive connections to the cerebral cortex. This structure plays a crucial role in regulating sleep, alertness, and wakefulness, besides influencing memory and learning through its connections to the hippocampus and parts of the limbic system.

lumbar vertebrae 3 (l3).cleaned_definition:
Positioned centrally among the five lumbar segments in the lower spine, this structure bears significant weight. It is robustly built, with its vertebral arch and the cylindrical centrum being notably large for movable vertebrae. Located in the mid-lumbar region, it faces a high risk of wear and tear, often being a prevalent source of chronic lower back discomfort. This organ's vertebral arch features short, notched pedicles leading to thick laminae, safeguarding a relatively spacious, triangular vertebral foramen for the spinal cord's passage. Each side presents a long, slender transverse process, devoid of transverse foramina. It possesses superior and inferior articular processes and facets for articulation with the adjacent lumbar segments. The spinous process is significantly broad, nearly rectangular, projecting horizontally to offer a robust anchorage for lower back muscles. 

From the posterior view, this organ and the one immediately below it create a square with their articular processes, whereas the lowest lumbar vertebra forms a horizontally stretched trapezoid. This structure differs from its three counterparts above by having a larger anterior than posterior dimension. Moreover, its spinous process, distinctively wide and four-sided, ends in a rough edge with a substantial notch.
relations: articulates with (via articular processes and facets)

myocardial edema.cleaned_definition: This condition results from an excessive buildup of fluid within the heart's middle muscular layer, altering its normal spatial relationships and potentially heightening pressure within the heart, which may impede its relaxation capabilities. The affected tissue experiences a change in shape and appearance due to this fluid accumulation, which can modify the heart's structure and functionality. Comprised mainly of cardiac muscle cells forming a dense cellular network, the heart's middle layer is organized into myocardial tissue layers encircling the heart's chambers. The introduction of excess fluid disrupts this intricate organization. This layer plays a pivotal role in the contraction and expansion of the heart walls, essential for efficiently moving blood into the systemic circulation. Excess fluid in this structure can adversely affect the heart chambers' operations and the movement of blood within the cardiovascular system.

myocardial scar.cleaned_definition: Located in the heart's muscle layer, this structure forms as a result of healed injuries or heart attacks. Its size, shape, and distribution can differ, with certain types not penetrating the entire heart muscle wall. The dense, whitish collagen that constitutes it is less elastic than the surrounding cardiac tissue, originating from an excess of collagen during the healing process. This inelasticity can interfere with the normal contractility and functioning of the heart. Within the heart, the affected tissue integrates into the complex, branched network of cardiac muscle cells, which are intricately connected and layered around the heart's chambers.

necrotic brain tumor core.cleaned_definition: This structure refers to a part within a brain tumor where tissue has succumbed due to insufficient blood flow. Its exact position varies as brain tumors themselves can manifest in different regions such as the cerebral hemispheres, the cerebellum, or the brainstem. When it comes to its shape and appearance, this part can differ, typically showcasing as an area of dead or deteriorating tissue. This distinction is often notable in imaging studies like MRI, where it might be seen as a zone lacking enhancement or exhibiting hypointensity. Its composition diverges from the healthier surrounding tissue due to the predominance of dead or decaying cells, a direct outcome of the poor vascular supply to the area. Its relationship with nearby anatomical entities hinges on the tumor's placement, potentially lying near essential structures like white matter tracts, deep brain components, or brain ventricles.

parietal lobe.cleaned_definition:
Located near the rear and summit of the cranium, this structure finds itself nestled between the frontal and occipital regions, and above the temporal area on each side of the brain. Occupying roughly a quarter of each hemisphere, it is of a triangular outline, with its lower and upper ends referred to as the inferior and superior parts, respectively.

This part of the brain plays a pivotal role in both sensation and perception, crucial for compiling sensory input into a unified experience and crafting a spatial framework to navigate our surroundings. It houses the somatosensory cortex, essential for processing touch, temperature, and pain among other sensations. Furthermore, it contributes to understanding spatial locations, managing visuomotor coordination, and interpreting auditory signals, even playing a part in recognizing emotional expressions.

As it processes and interprets somatosensory data, it enlightens us about objects through tactile sensations and our own body's positioning and motion. Moreover, its contribution to spatial navigation and reasoning cannot be overlooked, as it establishes communications with other cerebral regions, notably for enhancing visual comprehension and processing.

peripheral zone of prostate.cleaned_definition: This significant anatomical region, which constitutes around 70% of the glandular tissue in the prostate, runs from the base to the apex of the prostate along its posterior aspect, enveloping the distal part of the urethra. It resembles a disc-shaped mass of tissue, with ducts that extend laterally from the urethra, positioned lateral and distal to the verumontanum. This structure, being closest to the rectal wall at the rear of the prostate, is what a physician feels during a digital rectal exam (DRE). It is made up of branching glands, with ducts lined with secretory epithelial cells and basal cells, and is replete with numerous ductal structures. It is in this area that the occurrences of carcinomas, chronic prostatitis, and postinflammatory atrophy are notably higher compared to other regions. It has significant spatial relationships with the rectum, bladder, and levator ani muscle, making it a pivotal region for diagnostics and therapeutic interventions, especially considering its role in 70-80% of prostate cancer origins.
relations: levator ani muscle (of the pelvic floor)

right amygdala.cleaned_definition: This organ, primarily associated with emotional processes, is a critical region within the brain's limbic system, facilitating a wide range of emotional and memory-related functions. Situated in the medial temporal lobe, just ahead of the hippocampus, it boasts an almond shape. Comprising several nuclei, including the basolateral complex, the cortical nucleus, the central nucleus, and others. The basolateral complex itself is divided into lateral, basal, and accessory basal nuclei. Additionally, this structure is categorized as a component of the basal ganglia, positioned deep within the temporal lobes, lying at an almost level position with the eyes. This organ is integral in governing negative emotions such as fear and sadness and is implicated in the brain's reward circuitry. Its proximity to various sensory information conduits, notably those related to smell, vision, and hearing, underscores its complex functionality. Structurally, it encompasses numerous nuclei grouped into five primary clusters: basolateral nuclei, cortical-like nuclei, central nuclei, among others. The largest among these, the lateral nucleus, spans the organ's entire length, ensuring extensive intrinsic and external connections, particularly with the basal nucleus. In essence, this structure plays a pivotal role in the regulation of emotional processes, sensory information processing, and reward system engagement, highlighting its significance in the broader context of emotion and behavior understanding.

right angular gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located in the inferior parietal lobe, this structure finds itself at the anterolateral region of the occipital lobe, shaped like a horseshoe and tucked behind the supramarginal gyrus, classified under Brodmann area 39. This organ, with its U-shaped configuration, envelops the posterior portion of the superior temporal sulcus and is situated adjacently to the supramarginal gyrus. Comprising numerous folds, it resides within the lower part of the parietal lobe and exhibits a lesser degree of myelination than areas dedicated to specific sensory modalities. It establishes connections with a variety of cerebral cortex areas, including parts of the ipsilateral frontal region, and communicates with other parts through the superior longitudinal fasciculus. Furthermore, its connectivity extends through the dorsal splenium and isthmus of the corpus callosum, linking it with its counterpart. The surrounding borders include the intraparietal sulcus superiorly, the parieto-occipital sulcus caudally, and rostrally by the supramarginal gyrus.
relations: posterior part of the superior temporal sulcus
ipsilateral prefrontal, inferior and superior frontal, opercular regions
connected by (via dorsal splenium and isthmus)
left and right versions of this structure

right anterior cingulate gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located on the medial surface of the right cerebral hemisphere, this structure is integral to the limbic system, engaged in managing emotions and behaviors. It is tied to a variety of cognitive operations and has a connection to several neurocognitive conditions including Alzheimer's, anxiety, addiction, depression, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia. Its extension is from the subcallosal area in the frontal lobe to the isthmus, closely conforming to the shape of the corpus callosum but separated by the callosal sulcus, and lies beneath the superior frontal gyrus, with the cingulate sulcus acting as a boundary. This organ is distinguished by its extensive nature and is characterized by differences in cell architecture between its anterior and posterior sections, highlighting its diverse functionality from visceromotor activities to cognitive processing. It occupies a crucial position within the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere and is implicated in a range of cognitive functions and several psychiatric conditions, emphasizing its role in the pathogenesis of schizophrenia and other cognitive disorders. This structure is cradled between the cingulate and callosal sulcus sulci and sits atop the corpus callosum, demarcated from the superior frontal gyrus by the cingulate sulcus. It has linkage with the parietal and temporal lobes, which aids in controlling motor movements and spatial navigation, besides having connections that reach the midbrain and spinal cord, facilitating the relay of nerve signals across the central nervous system.
relations: medial surface of the right cerebral hemisphere
subcallosal gyrus in the frontal lobe to the isthmus
superior convexity of the corpus callosum
cingulate sulcus and the sulcus of the corpus callosum

right anterior temporal lobe lateral par.cleaned_definition: Located on the right side of the head, towards the front and side, this structure is positioned anteriorly and laterally within the brain, neighboring the frontal and parietal lobes. It lies superior and anterior to the temporal lobe, demarcated by the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure). The superior surface, which creates the base of the lateral sulcus, seamlessly connects with the superior temporal gyrus and is characterized by two diagonally aligned ridges, known as the transverse temporal gyri, forming the primary auditory cortex. This organ is encircled medially by the circular sulcus, which encompasses the insula, a cortical lobe lying within the expanded floor of the lateral sulcus. In terms of spatial orientation, it finds itself just posterior to the central sulcus that segregates the parietal lobe from the frontal lobe. Additionally, it resides near both the parietal and occipital lobes, with the separation marked by the parieto-occipital sulcus and the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).

right anterior temporal lobe medial part.cleaned_definition: This structure, located in the human brain, is pivotal for numerous functions such as memory, understanding language, and recognizing objects. It is found at the bottom middle portion of the brain, situated just behind the temples. Sitting above the brain stem and cerebellum, it lies beneath the frontal and parietal lobes, with the occipital lobe positioned behind it. Essential for declarative or long-term memory, this region encompasses the hippocampus along with the hippocampal regions, perirhinal, parahippocampal, and entorhinal neocortical areas. The primary auditory cortex resides in the Heschl gyri, formed early in ontogeny alongside the Sylvian fissure, which demarcates this area from the parietal and frontal lobes. This structure is integrated with vital anatomy parts such as Wernicke's area, Broca's area, and the limbic system, despite some of these sprawling into other lobes. Information exchange between the left and this side of the lobe occurs through the corpus callosum and other brain structures. Moreover, impairments in spatial working memory have been associated with lesions in the parahippocampal region within this area. In essence, it plays a significant role in cognitive functionalities tied to memory, language comprehension, and spatial working memory.
relations: situated at the bottom middle portion of
parietal and frontal lobes (via the Sylvian fissure)
Wernicke's area, Broca's area, and the limbic system

right cerebellum.cleaned_definition: This structure is part of the cerebellum, an ancient section of the brain found in humans and other animals. It resides at the brain's rear, nestled behind the brainstem and under the temporal and occipital lobes, lying beneath the cerebrum's posterior portion. This organ is shaped like a half-circle that wraps around the brainstem, characterized by horizontal grooves across its surface. Measuring approximately 4.5 inches in width, its height ranges from 1 to 1.5 inches at the center and 2 to 2.5 inches at the edges, weighing between 4.8 and 6 ounces in an average adult. This pinkish-gray area comprises the cerebellar cortex, an outer layer of folded brain tissue abundant in neurons, crucial for processing and integrating sensory information. The cerebellum is split into two hemispheres, each correlating to the opposite side of the body. Almost all of the cerebellum's neurons are housed within the cerebellar cortex, a highly convoluted tissue sheet. Embedded beneath this cortex, within the white matter, are the cerebellar deep nuclei, serving as the cerebellum's primary output channels. This structure is positioned at the brain's base, precisely above the neck's intersection with the skull, and is bifurcated into two hemispheres, each corresponding to a body side.

right fusiform gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located within the ventral temporal cortex, this structure is integral for high-level visual processing, such as recognizing faces, identifying objects, and reading. It is positioned between the parahippocampal gyrus medially and the lingual gyrus, and the inferior temporal gyrus laterally on the basal temporal and occipital cortex. Described as spindle-shaped, it's notably wider in the center and narrows at the ends, being the largest macro-anatomical feature in the ventral temporal cortex, outlined by the collateral sulcus and occipitotemporal sulcus. The mid-fusiform sulcus highlights a significant functional area believed to be critical for face processing. Predominantly, this organ is engaged in visual functions, especially concerning faces, bodies, and high spatial frequency stimuli. Resting on the basal surface of the temporal and occipital lobes and marked by the collateral sulcus and occipitotemporal sulcus, it nestles between the parahippocampal gyrus and the lingual gyrus medially, and the inferior temporal gyrus laterally. Its occipital segment is below the lingual gyrus, with the anterior temporal segment usually at the cerebral peduncles level, displaying a curved or pointed form. The posterior temporal artery and occipitotemporal arteries, branches of the posterior cerebral artery, supply blood to it.

right insula anterior inferior cortex.cleaned_definition: This structure is nestled deep within the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. Surrounding it anteriorly is the orbital prefrontal cortex, while the frontoparietal operculum covers it from above, and the temporal operculum lies beneath. Located at the deepest part, where the temporal lobe's mesial surface, anterior perforator substance, and the bottommost point of the insula converge, typically the area around the middle cerebral artery's bifurcation is found. Resembling an island, this separate lobe of the brain is encased by three opercula (frontal, parietal, temporal) that stem from the lobes encapsulating it. It comprises short and long gyri. From a cytoarchitectural perspective, it's categorized into anterior, middle, and posterior segments, corresponding to its functions tied to the advanced cortex, limbic system, basal ganglia, and autonomic system. It maintains extensive connections with frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes, as well as with the cingulate gyrus and subcortical entities like the amygdala and brainstem, playing a pivotal role in sensory, cognitive, and emotional processes.

right insula anterior short gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located within the cerebral cortex's insular lobe, specifically on the right side, this structure is part of the insular cortex, nestled deep in the lateral sulcus, famously known as the Sylvian fissure. This marks the division between the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe. Among the features of the insula are the three short gyri found at its front and two long gyri at the back, with this organ being one of the anterior trio. It stands out due to its grey matter ridge, encased by sulci. Its architecture includes a division into anterior agranular and posterior granular parts, with a transitional area in between. The anterior region, where this structure is found, is distinguished by a dense presence of large spindle-shaped neurons within layer 5, alongside pyramidal neurons, mirroring the cellular setup of the anterior cingulate cortex. Its positioning in the anterior insula means it is neighbored by the other two short gyri, demarcated by two pre-central sulci, and shares a crucial linkage to the anterior cingulate cortex, indicating a partnership in forming limbic sensory and motor areas.
relations: insular lobe of the cerebral cortex
frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe
a ridge of grey matter surrounded by sulci

right insula middle short gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a component of the insular cortex, a concealed area deep within the brain, integral to a variety of essential cognitive and behavioral functions, including aspects of sensorimotor roles, pain, emotion, attention, and decision-making processes. Nested under a complex network of blood vessels, its arterial nourishment stems from the M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery through perforating branches ascending at its inferior segment. These branches traverse the insular sulcus, with the superior trunk nourishing the anterior region and the inferior trunk responsible for the posterior area. Its morphology is part of an arrangement where three anterior short gyri and two posterior long gyri are delineated, with this organ being one of the anterior short gyri. Surrounded by the circular insular sulcus, it is concealed by adjacent cortical areas. A significant dividing feature within it is the central sulcus, creating an anterior sector that includes this structure among the three short gyri. Relations with other brain regions span the temporal and occipital lobes, as well as the opercular and the orbitofrontal cortex, with separation achieved via the circular insular sulcus. Additionally, the central insular sulcus demarcates the anterior from the posterior segments of the insula, further defining its position within the brain's intricate structure.
relations: supplied by (via M2 segment of the middle cerebral artery)

right insula posterior long gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a component of the insular cortex, critical for various cognitive and behavioral functions and nestled deep in the lateral sulcus, a major fissure delineating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe. It is characterized as a ridge within the posterior segment of the insula, making up part of the brain's grey matter, surrounded by sulci. Though specifics on its appearance are scarce, it forms a fraction of the insular cortex, which accounts for about 2% of the total cortical surface, participating in advanced neural networks involving the higher cortex and several other significant bodily systems. It establishes reciprocal connections with the secondary somatosensory cortex and is the recipient of signals from thalamic nuclei responsive to spinothalamic pathways, as well as from the ventromedial nucleus of the thalamus, bringing vital homeostatic information like pain and temperature senses. Its position allows for interactions with the secondary somatosensory cortex, the amygdaloid complex, and the thalamus, separated from adjacent opercular parts by the circular insular sulcus and is formed anteriorly by three short gyri and posteriorly by two long gyri.

right insula posterior short gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a specific part of the human brain, located deep within, hidden by the frontal, parietal, and temporal operculum layers. It's nestled in the posterior segment of the insula, which is segmented into anterior and posterior sections by the central insular sulcus. It belongs to the posterior section. This area is convoluted, with a typically smooth surface marked by a shallow anterior ridge or sulcus delineating the anterior insular boundary. Variability in size and orientation is common across different individuals. It is one of several gyri found here, surrounded by the circular insular sulcus and adjacent to two long gyri in the posterior zone. Its structural significance ties to the posterior insula, linking it with the secondary somatosensory cortex and noting input from the ventral posterior inferior thalamic nuclei, specifically handling homeostatic information like pain, temperature, and other tactile sensations.

right lateral ventricle excluding tempor.cleaned_definition: This organ, nestled within the cerebral hemisphere on the right side, forms a critical part of the brain's ventricular system, holding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It is characterized by its distinctive C-shape, comprising the body, and extending anteriorly and posteriorly into the frontal and occipital lobes respectively through its frontal and occipital horns. This structure begins its path through the interventricular foramina, connecting to the single, central third ventricle, highlighting its pivotal role in the CSF's production and circulation, thereby safeguarding the brain. The anterior horn progresses anteriorly from the foramina of Monro, delineated by the corpus callosum's genu, and the caudate nucleus's head, along with columns of the fornix, playing parts in its boundary formation. Its relation to adjacent brain structures like the thalamus and caudate nucleus, among others, underscores its intricate positioning and functional significance within the cerebral architecture.
relations: anterior wall and roof formed by
inferior portion of the medial wall formed by

right lateral ventricle temporal horn.cleaned_definition: Positioned within the temporal lobe, this structure exhibits a C-shaped profile, precisely mirroring the hemisphere's contour as it ventures anteroinferiorly. Formed as a cavity, it commences in the temporal lobe's inferior region, navigating through to conclude at the point of connection with the third ventricle through the interventricular foramina. It encompasses elements of the limbic system like the hippocampus. The base houses the pes hippocampi, dentate gyrus, and fimbriae of the hippocampus, among others, while its ceiling is constituted by temporal lobe fibers, and the medial aspects are predominantly formed by the hippocampus and related structures. Adjacent to it are critical neuroanatomical landmarks, including the tail of the caudate nucleus and the pes hippocampi at the anterior floor segment. The presence of the choroid plexus distinguishes it further, although it is absent in the anterior and posterior horns.
relations: contains (in the middle part of the floor)
contains (in the middle part of the floor)
contains (in the middle part of the floor)
inferior horn from the lateral ventricle

right medial orbital gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located within the frontal lobe of the human brain, specifically on its inferior or orbital surface, this structure is distinguished by its unique position, form, and connections with surrounding anatomical entities. Positioned on the right inferior side of the frontal lobe, it rests on the orbital plate of the frontal bone, and is characterized by its spindle-shaped appearance. Divided into sections by a prominent H-shaped sulcus, this area is defined by an antero-posterior sulcus known as the olfactory sulcus, towards its medial side, leading into the straight gyrus and connecting to the superior frontal gyrus on the medial aspect. This organ notably sits in the anterior cranial fossa, directly above the orbital plate of the frontal bone, and is flanked by other gyri, separated by noticeable sulci. It mainly consists of grey matter and is crucial for the enhancement of cognitive abilities. Although specific clinical significances weren't detailed, alterations in its structure are linked to various neurological conditions.
relations: orbital plate of the frontal bone
superior frontal gyrus on the medial surface

right middle and inferior temporal gyrus.cleaned_definition: Situated in the temporal lobe, these structures are crucial components of the ventral visual pathway, essential for processing visually-related cognitive tasks such as face recognition and mental imagery. The segment directly above the lower one is demarcated by the inferior temporal sulcus, playing a significant role in language processes and semantic memory. On its lower side, this region is bounded by the occipital-temporal sulcus, distinguishing it from the fusiform gyrus. Reductions in gray matter volume within these areas have been observed in chronic schizophrenia, highlighting their significance in various neurological conditions. These gyri, therefore, are vital for integrating sensory information and engaging in complex visual perception tasks.
relations: superior temporal gyrus and inferior temporal gyrus
separated from (by the inferior temporal sulcus)

right middle frontal gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a key aspect of the frontal lobe's anatomy, characterized by its wide and fusiform shape, nestled between two critical sulci. It occupies a significant portion - roughly one-third - of the frontal lobe, constituting a grey matter ridge that is framed by sulci. This organ's broad size in the middle tapers off towards both ends, delineated by the inferior and superior frontal sulci, as well as the precentral sulcus at its rear. It's positioned strategically, anterior to regions crucial for various brain functions, facilitating complex spatial relationships with neighboring anatomical landmarks.

right nucleus accumbens.cleaned_definition: Located in the basal forebrain, this structure is pivotal to the ventral striatum, playing a crucial role in regulating the limbic system's functions such as motivation, affect, and reward. Present on both sides of the cerebral hemisphere, it is nestled between the caudate and the putamen. Comprising a shell and a core, its precise shape and topography have been the subject of anatomical 3D reconstructions to make it a safer target for stereotactic procedures. Being a fundamental part of the basal ganglia and the primary component of the ventral striatum, it also forms a critical portion of the reward system, notably through its significant connections with the ventral tegmental area along the mesolimbic dopamine pathway.

right optic radiation.cleaned_definition: This structure in human anatomy is a vital component of the visual system, tasked with transferring visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus to the primary visual cortex. It is a bundle of myelinated nerve fibers, deeply intertwined with the visual processing pathways. Originating from the lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus, these fibers extend to the primary visual cortex found in the occipital lobe. They are supplied by deep branches of the middle and posterior cerebral arteries. Each brain hemisphere houses one such tract, with the structure taking on a pivotal role in conveying visual inputs via its two divisions towards the visual cortex, nestled along the calcarine fissure. When lesions affect only this structure on one side, a specific type of visual field defect known as quadrantanopia can occur. It's noteworthy for its early myelin maturation, making it susceptible to damage, particularly during epilepsy surgery. Hence, its precise location relative to defined anatomical landmarks is critical in the context of preoperative planning to mitigate the risk of postsurgical visual impairments.
relations: lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus
deep branches of the middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
visual cortex along the calcarine fissure

right pallidum.cleaned_definition: This structure, known as the globus pallidus, forms an integral part of the basal ganglia within the brain's telencephalon, contributing to the extrapyramidal system. It comprises an external segment (GPe) and an internal segment (GPi), with the former enveloping the latter. Distinctly pale in appearance, it lies deep within the cerebral hemispheres, tasked with crucial motor control functions, especially in regulating voluntary movements. Its proximity to the putamen and connections with other parts of the striatum, like the caudate nucleus and putamen, underscore its significant role in neurological pathways.

right postcentral gyrus.cleaned_definition: Situated on the lateral surface of the parietal lobes, this structure is prominently positioned between the central sulcus and postcentral sulcus. It encompasses the primary somatosensory cortex, crucial for the perception of bodily sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and pain. This organ is key in proprioception and the integration of somatic stimuli with memory. As a core component of the somatosensory system, it occupies a central role in tactile sensation. The topographic sensory distribution within this structure reflects detailed spatial patterns that correspond to tactile inputs from various body parts. The primary somatosensory cortex within it is organized systematically, demonstrating cortical representations in an ordered fashion. Although there are variations across individuals and between the hemispheres, this structure typically includes the secondary somatosensory cortex as well. It extends to the precentral gyrus through its continuity on both medial and superolateral aspects, connecting via the paracentral lobule and the subcentral gyrus. Located in the parietal lobe and receiving its blood supply from the middle cerebral artery, this gyrus is a significant grey matter ridge that plays an indispensable role in the sensory interpretation of somatic stimuli.
relations: continuous with (on both the medial and superolateral aspects)
connected to (via the paracentral lobule and the subcentral gyrus)

right posterior temporal lobe.cleaned_definition:
This part of the human brain is integral to the cerebral cortex, vital for roles in processing memory, sound, vision, and language. It finds its position in the brain's bottom middle, just behind the temples and above the cerebellum and brain stem. This structure reaches upwards to the Sylvian fissure and extends back to an imaginary line, the lateral parietotemporal line. This demarcation separates it from the superiorly located inferior parietal lobule of the parietal lobe and the inferiorly situated occipital lobe. Resting in the middle cranial fossa, it is bordered in front by the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, below by the superior surface of the petrous part of the temporal bone, and to the side by the squamous part of the temporal bone coupled with the parietal bone. 

Significant components within this structure include Wernicke's area, Broca's area, and the limbic system, the latter being responsible for emotional regulation and memory acquisition. It also plays a part in processing spatial information and is functionally connected to various regions including the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, as well as the hippocampus.

Adjacent to the frontal and parietal lobes, with the occipital lobe located directly behind, this area sits below the parietal lobe, beneath the lateral fissure, closer to the brain's base.
relations: greater wing of the sphenoid bone
superior surface of the petrous part of the temporal bone
squamous part of the temporal bone and the adjoining parietal bone

right pre-subgenual frontal cortex.cleaned_definition: Situated in the human brain, this structure is located within the frontal cortex, specifically on its anteriormost part. It occupies areas across all three surfaces of the frontal lobe, including orbital, medial, and lateral aspects. This area is housed within the anterior cranial fossa, resting above the orbital plate of the frontal bone, and extends through one-third of the cerebral hemisphere from the frontal pole to the central sulcus. This marks its boundary with the parietal lobe behind it. The surface of this brain region is defined by the characteristic cortical patterns of gyri and sulci, which are its folds and depressions, respectively. Known for its involvement in numerous high-level cognitive functions such as decision-making, motivation, problem-solving, planning, attention, reasoning, personality expression, and social cognition, it represents a significant area within the frontal cortex.
relations: anteriormost portion of the frontal lobe
orbital, medial, and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobe
orbital plate of the frontal bone

right putamen.cleaned_definition: Situated in the forebrain, this structure contributes to the formation of the dorsal striatum alongside the caudate nucleus, marking the periphery of the basal ganglia group, which is well connected to other significant brain regions. Part of the lentiform nucleus, known for its lens-like shape, it is intricately linked with the caudate nucleus, nucleus accumbens, and globus pallidus, collectively referred to as the corpus striatum. Housing similar neuronal types and circuits as those found in the caudate nucleus, many experts view the dorsal striatum essentially as a unified entity, albeit segmented into two by the internal capsule. Its strategic position ensures a complex network of interactions crucial for limb movement, making it a central figure in the corpus striatum's spatial dynamics.

right straight gyrus.cleaned_definition: Located in the frontal lobe, this structure is immediately adjacent to the longitudinal fissure, nestled beside the medial orbital gyrus and olfactory tract. It seamlessly connects with the superior frontal gyrus on the medial surface of the brain. This organ, depicted in red or yellow across various brain illustrations, lies on the orbital plate of the frontal bone, stretching from the frontal pole to the central sulcus, delineating the separation from the parietal lobe. Despite being a significant part of the frontal lobe, adjacent to the longitudinal fissure and integrally connected with the superior frontal gyrus, its precise role in brain function remains to be fully uncovered.
relations: orbital plate of the frontal bone

right subcallosal area.cleaned_definition: This structure is identified as a petite, triangular zone located on the medial aspect of the hemisphere, positioned anteriorly to the subcallosal gyrus. It is delineated from the latter by the posterior parolfactory sulcus and is bounded at the front by the anterior parolfactory sulcus. This organ admirably connects below with the olfactory trigone and establishes continuity above and anteriorly with the cingulate gyrus. The irrelevant content has been omitted to focus on the essential anatomical relationships and structural description.
relations: subcallosal gyrus (via the posterior parolfactory sulcus)

right subgenual frontal cortex.cleaned_definition: This structure is a specific area within the frontal lobe of the human brain, crucial for emotional regulation and mood control. It occupies one-third of the cerebral hemisphere, extending from the most anterior part, the frontal pole, to the central sulcus, delineating it from the parietal lobe. This organ is located in the ventromedial region of the prefrontal cortex and exhibits a folded appearance characteristic of the frontal lobe, with gyri and sulci. It is intimately linked with the limbic system, specifically with the amygdala, hippocampus, and cingulate gyrus, forming essential connections for emotional processing and regulation.

right substantia nigra.cleaned_definition: Located in the midbrain, posterior to the crus cerebri fibers of the cerebral peduncle, this structure is a significant part of the midbrain. It's divided into two main areas, each with distinct functions: the darkly pigmented pars compacta, rich in neuromelanin, and the pars reticulata. This pigmentation makes it stand out compared to surrounding areas. The former is crucial for dopamine supply to the basal ganglia circuit, impacting the striatum, while the latter facilitates communication from the basal ganglia to various brain structures. As a central element in the basal ganglia network, it plays a pivotal role in dopamine production, essential for regulating movements and muscle tone. This structure is integral to the brain's chemical signaling, influencing learning, mood, judgment, decision-making, and motor functions.
relations: crus cerebri fibers of the cerebral peduncle

right superior frontal gyrus.cleaned_definition: This structure, located in the frontal lobe, stands out for its strategic positioning, superior and anterior to the temporal lobe, demarcated from it by the lateral sulcus. Inferiorly, it finds itself beneath the superior frontal sulcus, which also distinguishes it from the middle frontal gyrus. As a ridge-like elevation of the cerebral cortex, surrounded by sulci, it significantly enhances the brain's surface area and, consequently, its cognitive functions. Comprising gray matter, this organ plays a crucial role in the neural network responsible for working memory and spatial processing, aiding in impulse control and the modulation of inhibitory control and motor urgency. Spatially, it is connected to various regions within the cerebral cortex, such as the prefrontal, inferior and superior frontal, and opercular regions, which are paramount in attention and calculation. Additionally, its connections extend to the parahippocampal gyrus and hippocampus, underscoring its involvement in memory and spatial orientation.
relations: ipsilateral prefrontal, inferior and superior frontal, and opercular regions of the cerebral cortex

right superior temporal gyrus anterior p.cleaned_definition: Located on the human brain's temporal lobe, laterally near the head and above the ear, this structure is delineated by the lateral and superior temporal sulci, with a theoretical boundary extending from the preoccipital notch to the lateral sulcus at its rear. Its appearance on the supratemporal plane is distinguished by comprising Heschl's gyrus (HG), planum polare, and planum temporale, where HG stretches laterally into this region and medially towards the insular cortex. HG finds its borders with planum polare at the front and planum temporale at the back. This organ holds significant brain structures including Brodmann areas 41 and 42, recognized for housing the auditory cortex. This cortex is paramount for hearing. The primary and secondary auditory areas here are essential for processing sounds from the medial geniculate nucleus. Moreover, the posterior section of area 22 is crucial for language comprehension. This area is neatly situated on the supratemporal plane, surrounded by the lateral sulcus on the top, and the superior temporal sulcus below, while integrating smoothly with the temporal lobe's superior surface.

right superior temporal gyrus middle par.cleaned_definition: This structure is located in the temporal lobe of the human brain, positioned laterally to the head and somewhat above the external ear. It is delineated by the lateral sulcus on its upper boundary and the superior temporal sulcus below, with an imaginary line from the preoccipital notch to the lateral sulcus marking its posterior limit. Not explicitly detailed in shape and appearance, it houses significant brain structures including Brodmann areas 41 and 42, which encompass the auditory cortex responsible for sound perception. It lacks connections with lateral and medial structures due to the anterior-posterior orientation of white matter anatomy. This organ is contiguous with the transverse temporal gyri, located on the lateral sulcus's floor, and extends anterolaterally from the circular sulcus surrounding the insula. The superior temporal sulcus, running parallel and slightly superior to the lateral sulcus, separates this organ from adjacent gyri, ending near the angular gyrus in the parietal lobe. Located between the superior and inferior temporal gyri, this region largely corresponds to Brodmann area 21.
relations: an imaginary line from the preoccipital notch to the lateral sulcus

right supramarginal gyrus.cleaned_definition:
This organ is a portion of the parietal lobe, identified as Brodmann area 40, crucial for language perception and understanding. Injuries here may lead to receptive aphasia. Shaped like a horseshoe, it tops the posterior ascending branch of the lateral sulcus, positioned just before the angular gyrus. Towards the front, it integrates with the lower part of the postcentral gyrus. 

In the right hemisphere, this structure is essential for empathetic controls towards others, with disruptions to its neurons causing a lack of empathy by projecting emotions incorrectly.

Included in the somatosensory association cortex, this organ helps interpret tactile sensory information and is pivotal in understanding physical space and limb placement. Furthermore, it participates in various functions such as language, numerical processing, spatial awareness, memory access, focus, and social cognition.
relations: posterior ascending ramus of the lateral sulcus

right thalamus.cleaned_definition: This structure is a component of the diencephalon, primarily composed of gray matter and crucial for various physiological roles, such as transmitting sensory and motor signals and managing consciousness and alertness. Shaped like an egg, it stretches along the anteroposterior axis, showcasing an ovoid appearance that becomes wider towards the back. Internally, this organ houses several nuclei, each tasked with specific functions. A Y-shaped white matter structure, known as the internal medullary lamina, divides it approximately into three sections: the anterior, medial, and lateral parts. Its location, deep within the forebrain and positioned above the midbrain, places it on either side of the third ventricle, making it integral to the brain's overall function. Although its appearance might seem simplistic, highlighting two notable protuberances on its posteroventral surface distinguishes it. Communicating through the interthalamic adhesion, this organ and its counterpart work together seamlessly. The posterior region is notably expanded, forming the pulvinar, which prominently sits over the superior colliculus, and its lower surface merges with the midbrain's tegmentum.

stroke.cleaned_definition: This medical emergency occurs when there's a burst or blockage in one of the brain's blood vessels, depriving brain cells of oxygen and leading to their rapid demise. This can cause significant disability or even be fatal if not quickly addressed. The specific area of the brain impacted can determine the scope and type of bodily functions affected, although describing this condition in terms of shape, appearance, or structure isn't common practice. The focus is rather on its implications for the brain and overall health.

temporal lobe.cleaned_definition: This region, representing over 20% of the neocortical volume, finds its place within the middle cranial fossa, adjacent to the temporal bone. Its boundaries are notably marked on the lateral side by the lateral sulcus above, and a line stretching from the parieto-occipital sulcus's peak to the preoccipital notch behind. The area below is confined by the middle cranial fossa. Positioned beneath the parietal lobe and the lateral fissure, closer to the base of the skull, this structure is not isolated but encompasses critical areas like the hippocampus, and the parahippocampal regions, essential for long-term memory retention. It stretches upwards to meet the Sylvian fissure and towards the back until it arrives at a conceptual division, setting it apart from the inferior parietal lobule on top and the occipital lobe at the back. Within this area, pivotal regions include areas responsible for language processing and the limbic system, which interacts with other lobes like the frontal and parietal lobes. It's rich in subcortical white matter, enclosing pathways like the arcuate fasciculus and Meyer's loop, which is part of the geniculocalcarine tract.

thalamus.cleaned_definition: Located deep within the brain, just superior to the brain stem and nestled between the cerebral cortex and the midbrain, this structure embraces the third ventricle and forms a part of the diencephalon subdivision. It comprises two symmetrical entities originated from the diencephalon. Each segment is elongated, adopting an ovoid shape, tapering at the anterior end and becoming broader posteriorly, with a couple of prominences noticeable on its posteroventral facet. Composed of approximately 60 distinct nuclei, this Gray matter structure is divided by a Y-shaped white matter formation known as the internal medullary lamina into three primary segments: anterior, medial, and lateral. These halves communicate through the interthalamic adhesion. This organ is crucial within the diencephalon region, incorporating the hypothalamus, subthalamus, and epithalamus. Its functional connections extend to the hippocampus as part of the extended hippocampal system focusing on spatial memory and sensory data processing. The relationship to the mesio-temporal lobe underlines its role in differentiating between recollective and familiarity memory functions. Additionally, its links with the hippocampus and other limbic system regions underscore its contributions to episodic memory, as well as learning and emotional processes.

third ventricle.cleaned_definition:
This narrow, funnel-shaped cavity, positioned at the brain's midline and encased within the diencephalon between the forebrain's two hemispheres, represents a central component of the brain's ventricular system. It exhibits a unique cuboid structure, comprising a roof, floor, and four enclosing walls (anterior, posterior, and two lateral sides). The roof is chiefly composed of the tela chorioidea - a section of the choroid plexus. Meanwhile, the floor is constructed from hypothalamic territories. The significance of its four walls, especially the anterior wall, becomes evident through various radiological visualization techniques.

Boundaries of this structure include several noteworthy formations. Its posterior wall is constituted by elements such as the habenular commissure, pineal recess, posterior commissure, and the entry for the cerebral aqueduct. The base is defined by the optic chiasma, tuber cinereum, infundibulum, and mamillary bodies, beyond which the midbrain's tegmentum extends. Lastly, the top part relates closely to both the fornix and corpus callosum, indicating its intricate relation with other vital brain structures.
relations: communicates with (via cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius)
habenular commissure, pineal recess, posterior commissure
optic chiasma, tuber cinereum, infundibulum, mamillary bodies

tibia bone.cleaned_definition: Located in the lower front segment of the leg, it stands as the second largest structure in the human body, positioned immediately to the inside of the fibula. This long, narrow organ, which boasts a triangular cross-section, features a flat top at one end for knee formation, extended midsection, and a notched bottom for ankle articulation. The top section holds two condyles that interact with the femur's condyles. Its construction includes a diaphysis and two epiphyses, engaging in both knee and ankle joints. This structure serves as a crucial attachment point for leg muscles and plays a vital role in bearing the leg's weight. It is interlinked with the fibula by an interosseous membrane throughout its length. Ossification of this organ begins from three points, with variations in completion times based on gender.

transition zone of prostate.cleaned_definition:
This organ encases the urethra at the point where it intersects with the prostate gland, playing a pivotal role in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the normal gland enlargement seen in aging that may lead to urinary complications. Initially compact in young adults, this structure experiences growth over a lifetime, thus occupying an increased proportion of the gland. Constituting 10% of the glandular tissue within the prostate, it also contributes to 20% of the adenocarcinomas. With the prostate being composed of roughly 70% glandular tissue and 30% fibromuscular stroma, this zone's significance cannot be understated. Positioned in the pelvis, it finds itself nestled between other key anatomical structures.

Relation: encases, Anatomical structure: urethra
Relation: surrounded by, Anatomical structure: rectum (posteriorly)
Relation: sits below, Anatomical structure: bladder (superiorly)
Relation: lies superior to, Anatomical structure: seminal vesicles 
Relation: each joins, Anatomical structure: ductus deferens (forms ejaculatory duct)

urinary bladder.cleaned_definition: Located in the pelvic cavity, this organ is positioned posterior to the symphysis pubis and beneath the parietal peritoneum. In males, it is found between the pubic bone and the rectum, and in females, it lies in front of the vagina and uterus. This structure connects with the ureters at the top and the urethra at the bottom. Its appearance changes with the urine volume; it can be oval when full and resembles a pear shape when empty, consisting of an apex, a base, neck, superior surface, and two inferolateral surfaces. This muscular and hollow organ has a folded internal lining to expand and hold up to 400-600ml of urine. Covered by peritoneum on its superior and parts of the posterior sides and by endopelvic fascia elsewhere, this distensible organ receives blood from the superior and inferior vesical arteries, alongside other vessels like the uterine and vaginal arteries in females. It is also innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve fibers.
relations: pubic bone (in front) and rectum (in back) for males
peritoneum (superior and part of the posterior surfaces)
